The Punjab Raj Bhawan has suspended the upcoming outside engagements as a precautionary measure.

To deal with any eventuality, the Administration has identified Infosys Sarai adjoining PGIMER with a provision of 262 beds for quarantine of patients especially for asymptomatic patients travelling from the COVID- 19 affected countries.

Apart from this, the residents have been provided with a helpline no 9779558282 on 24X7 for any type of queries related to COVID – 19 and a dedicated Ambulance is available 24X7 for shifting and screening of patients thereof.

Three teams of SDMs along with the area DSP and Drug Inspectors have also been constituted to ensure that there is no hoarding of any medicines, masks, sanitizer etc.

A day before, the Chandigarh Transport Undertaking (CTU) had decided to sanitize its buses as a precautionary measure. The Administration is also putting up posters related to Do’s and Don’ts on Coronavirus in the buses for public awareness.

The CTU has a fleet of 533 buses operating from four depots and as many as two lakh commuters use CTU buses every day.

SUSPECTED CORONAVIRUS CASE OF DOCTOR REPORTED IN PGIMER

A junior resident doctor from Department of Virology, PGIMER has been kept in Communicable Disease (CD) ward under suspicion of COVID-19, said a spokesperson of PGIMER on Friday.

The doctor has a history of visiting Kerala, which has so far witnessed highest number of cases of Coronavirus patients.

Giving details of the doctor, the spokesperson said that she has been suffering from fever and cough from last three days. Sampling has been done and her reports are awaited, the spokesperson added.

The PGIMER had on March 7 started the testing of COVID-19 itself. Currently, 142 travelers are under home surveillance in Chandigarh.

All suspected cases of Coronavirus admitted to the PGIMER has been tested negative till Friday evening.

A day before, the PGIMER had decided to cancel all its national and international conferences as a preventive measure to contain the spread of Coronavirus.

Title: Haryana Govt shuts all universities, colleges till March 31
Article:
A day after declaring Coronavirus as an epidemic, Haryana Government on Friday shut all universities and colleges in the State till March 31.

The Government also decided to close schools in five districts -- Gurugram, Sonepat, Rohtak, Jhajjar and Faridabad till March 31, officials said.

However, school students in these districts will take their exams as per schedule, according to a school education department order.

According to an advisory issued by the Panchkula based Director General of Higher Education, "The State Government has decided that all universities and colleges situated in Haryana state will be closed till March 31 as a precautionary measure."

The department of school education Haryana, meanwhile, in its order stated, "All the Government as well as private schools situated in Sonepat, Rohtak, Jhajjar, Faridabad and Gurugram districts will remain closed till March 31 with immediate effect, except for holding examinations."

"The students will attend the school only to take the board exams, annual exams and assessment exams, March 2020 as per previous schedule. However, all the teaching and non-teaching staff members will attend the school as usual," it said, adding that schools in remaining districts shall function as per normal schedule.

The State Government had on Thursday declared the coronavirus an epidemic and Health Minister Anil Vij had advised people to avoid large gatherings.

Title: Corona Virus prevention: Orientation programme underway at BTR
Article:
Field Director, Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve, Vincent Rahim, informed that an orientation programme is being conducted in the Reserve in collaboration with the Health Department for prevention from Corona Virus.

In the programme held on the second Wednesday of January, February and March, RMO Dr Sandipak Singh and Nodal Officer Corona Virus Anil Singh gave information to the resort managers, gypsy operators, tourist guides and forest personnel regarding Corona virus and its prevention.

In the orientation programme held at the Eco Training Centre, Dr Singh informed that an alert has been issued against Corona in all medical colleges, district hospitals and primary health centres of the State. All possible arrangements for treatment have been made in these hospitals.

Dr Singh said that symptoms of patients affected by Corona virus are similar to pneumonia. The affected person gets symptoms like cold, sore throat, difficulty in breathing, cough, fever and kidney failure. Its virus spreads through the air. Do not shake hands with a person suffering from cold, fever etc. Keep a distance of at least 6 feet because the virus caused by sneeze, cough, etc. of the affected person cannot go far.

Wash hands several times a day with soap and water or use a sanitiser. Use disposable tissue paper when coughing and sneezing. Throw away the used tissue paper and wash your hands.

Do not touch eyes, nose and mouth without washing hands. If there is no tissue paper, use your arm while sneezing and coughing. Wear an N-95 mask to protect against the virus. Avoid proximity with people infected with a cold or flu.

Title: Kaushik reviews construction works in Haridwar
Article:
Urban Development minister Madan Kaushik held a review meeting of the construction works for underground power line, water, sewer line and gas pipeline along with the Haridwar district magistrate C Ravishankar here on Friday. During the review, Kaushik instructed the officials of the departments concerned to work in coordination with each other.

He said that the road, electricity and water system should be repaired and officers should discharge their duties diligently.

He gave strict instructions to Public Works Department officials to complete the construction works on the roads in time and take special care of quality.

He told the officials of the electricity department that wires are hanging above the main road and only meters have been installed on them. These should be corrected immediately.

He also directed the officials of the PWD and the Municipal Corporation of Haridwar to immediately repair the roads in view of the rain.

He instructed national highway officials to fill potholes on the highway from Jatwada bridge to Shantikunj at war footing and complete the work within a week. Strict action will be taken if the work is found to be incomplete during inspection, he warned.

Kaushik inquired from the officials about the problems faced in the execution of works. On the condition of waterlogging at the Pavan Dham intersection, strict instructions were given for facilitating the drainage of water so that it can be resolved. The district magistrate said that if any pipeline is broken by any department while working, then the officials of the department concerned will be informed to that immediate action is taken to fix it. The district magistrate also gave guidelines regarding the problem of cable network wiring. Municipal commissioner Narendra Bhandari, executive engineer of underground power line Pawan Kumar, superintending engineer SC Pandey, PWD executive engineer Deepak Kumar, Peyjal Nigam executive engineers Ajay Kumar, Mohammed Misham and other officials concerned were also present in the meeting.

Title: Man arrested for murder on Holi
Article:
The police have arrested a man accused of murdering another man on the occasion of Holi in Kankhal area of Haridwar.

Informing the media about this on Friday, the Haridwar senior superintendent of police Senthil Avoodai Krishnaraj S said that the accused has confessed to having killed the man since he had an illicit relationship with the deceased’s wife.

The SSP informed that the body of a man was found by the police amidst the bushes on an empty plot in Kankhal on Holi. The body was identified as that of local resident Deepak.

His brother Kuldeep Singh filed a case against unknown assailant in the police station.

The police questioned the family members of the victim and check the CCTV camera footage in the area but no substantial clue could be found. However, on Friday, an informant tipped off the police about the location of the murder accused.

After being arrested by the police, the accused identified himself as Kankhal resident Ravi Kumar. He said that he had an affair with Deepak’s wife.

On the occasion of Holi, he had an argument with Deepak after which he hit him on the head with a brick and ran away from the spot. SP City Kamlesh Upadhyay and CO City Abhay Pratap Singh were also present during the press conference.

Title: DSF to develop Rudraksha Forest in Uttarkashi
Article:
The Dinesh Shahra Foundation (DSF) has claimed that it will develop a Rudraksha Vana (a forest of Rudraksha trees) in Uttarkashi district of Uttarakhand.

The announcement was made by the chairman of DSF, Dinesh Shahra in Rishikesh on Friday in presence of Swami Chidanand Saraswati of Parmarth Niketan.

He claimed that a team of forestry experts from DSF would be deployed for location identification and creation of a blueprint for the development of the proposed Rudraksha Van in Uttarkashi. Apart from ecological benefits, the initiative will create employment in priority sectors for the locals and help promote tourism in the region, he said. About 10000 saplings of Rudraksha would be planted in the area selected for the project.

Title: Protesters to approach HC against Govt
Article:
Claiming that the shifting of the protest site from near the Parade Ground to Adhoiwala away from the city center as a sign of the state government’s dictatorial attitude, some protesting groups and associations have decided to go to Uttarakhand High Court against the government. Besides, some protesting groups resumed their protest in Gandhi Park instead of the new protest site.

All the protesting groups were reportedly served notice by March 9 to shift their protest on the new protest site near Adhoiwala after the Holi festival.

On March 11, the protesters were not ready to vacate the place even after the permission approved to protest on the old protest site near Parade Ground was revoked by the city magistrate. Reportedly when the protesters did not shift the protest till the late evening, the police detained some of the protesters and later dropped them on the new protest site.The protesting groups and associations are calling such actions of the government and police the suppression of citizens and their rights in a democratic country. According to the state president of Anganwadi workers association Rekha Negi, “Forcing the protesters to vacate the protest site is unethical under a democratic government. The district administration has allotted the new protest site in an area which is quite far from the center of the city.

The protesters demonstrate for their rights so that the administration can pay attention to the complaints and issues of protesters. Who is going to listen to us in this deserted place?”“We will not bear such kind of oppressive behaviour of the government. All the protesting groups and few other associations will file a case in High Court against the city administration in few days,” added Negi.

Other protesting groups also agreed with Negi saying that they will too file the case against the misconduct of administration towards the protesters. “Police detained us when we were just asking for the annulment of the Forest Guard Recruitment Exam because of the fraud in its recruitment procedure.

We were left at a distant location in Adhoiwala around 3 AM. Should this kind of incident happen in an independent country? We will definitely join the other protesting groups in filing the court case against the administration,” said one of the protesting members of Uttarakhand Unemployed Organisation (UUO) Sanjay Panwar. The protesting members of Gairsain Rajdhani Nirman Abhiyan (GRNA) are also considering going to court against the government.

According to one of its protesting members Pradeep Chaudhary, “Earlier the government just used to neglect the protesters, now it is pushing them away from the center of the city so that no one can notice the protesters and their struggles.

No protester will tolerate this corrupt behaviour and the dictatorship of Uttarakhand Government and the necessary steps will be taken by the GRNA and if that will include filing a case against the government, we will do that too.”Meanwhile, Dehradun organiser of anti-CAA protest and senior advocate Razia Beig resumed the protest in Gandhi Park on Friday claiming the new protest site to be unsuitable for the protest, especially during the rainy days.

According to her, heap of garbage is lying below the surface in the new site through which insects have started to emerge on the surface during the rain. Beig said that she will also be joining others in filing a court case against the administration.

Title: Administration on toes against coronavirus
Article:
The district administration has tightened its belt to fight Coronavirus. According to information so far 19 samples (nose and throat swab) from different parts of the State have been sent for detection of coronavirus. Out of which 17 have turned negative and two results are awaited.

Moreover isolation wards have been set up in all the medical colleges cum hospitals at Jamshedpur including Tata Main Hospital and MGM Medical College and Hospital. There are a total of 70 beds at the isolation wards in different medical colleges. While isolation wards have been set up in the district hospitals in the 19 districts Jamshedpur Sadar Hospital also has a four-bed isolation ward.

All the isolation wards have adequate provision of masks, drugs, hand sanitisers, water, soaps and other medical requirements. 104 is the 24x7 helpline number and so far 1171 calls pertaining to coronavirus have been attended in Jharkhand.

“ We are spreading awareness among people. We have not found a single positive case of Corona in the city, so there is no need to panic. But we need to be alert just the same. We have conducted a review meeting and have asked the health officials concerned to keep an eye,” said official.

The official of health department said its is important people to Clean hands frequently with alcohol based sanitizer or soap in running water for at least 20 seconds scrubbing all parts of both the hands properly.

They should cover face while sneezing or coughing.

He noted that common symptoms of novel coronavirus are running nose, sore throat, dry cough, fever, tiredness difficulty breathing. Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, and sore throat.

Title: U’khand ready to meet threat: CM
Article:
In view of the threat posed by the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), the health department of Uttarakhand has set up quarantine facilities in six districts of Dehradun, Haridwar, Nainital, Udham Singh Nagar, Champawat and Pithoragarh. In these centres 801 people can be quarantined at a time.

Addressing media persons here on Friday, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said that the state government is fully prepared to combat the disease. He said that no patient of the disease has so far been reported from the state and 175 suspected patients are being kept under observation at present.

In response to a question on his government’s decision to hold programmes in all 70 assembly constituencies to celebrate three years in office, the CM said things are regularly being monitored.

On upcoming Char Dham Yatra for which lakhs of pilgrims arrive in the state, the CM said that there is time left in commencement of Yatra and the threat of disease would probably reduce by the time the Yatra starts.

Rawat informed that samples of 17 suspected patients have been sent for testing for COVID-19 and out of them 12 patients (ten from Dehradun and two from Haridwar) were found negative for the disease. Reports of five suspected patients are awaited.

Asking the people not to get panicky due to he disease, the CM said that isolation facility for suspected patients, masks and medicines are available in sufficient numbers. He said the health workers have been trained and all those coming from Nepal are being screened.

“The heath workers have so far screened 22,968 people at check points of Banbasa, Tanakpur, Dharchula, Baluakot, Jauljivi, Jhulaghat, Dyura and Khatima on Indo -Nepal border. Similarly teams of health department are screening passengers at all the airports. A total of 41,508 passengers have so far been screened at airports,’’ he said. The CM added that 351 out of 526 persons who had travelled to the affected countries have completed the mandatory 28 days of observation.

He said that isolation ward for the suspected patients of the disease have been set up at all the major hospitals and medical colleges and 337 beds have been kept in reserve for the patients in these hospitals.

The CM added that the health department has adequate stocks of different kind of masks, disinfectants and other things required to combat the disease.The health department teams are undertaking awareness campaigns and advisory to the hotels regarding the foreign guests have been issued. The CM accepted that the threat of the disease has affected the tourism industry but the first priority of the government is to ensure safety of people from the disease.

He said that rapid response teams have been constituted at district level and the Asha workers and the ANMs are engaged in awareness campaigns at block and village level. A helpline number 104 has been released regarding information for the disease. The samples of the suspected patients are being collected at All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Rishikesh, Doon medical college hospital and Haldwani medical college hospital.

Title: Tata Steel suspends all business travel of employees
Article:
In view of COVID-19 being reported in several cities, Tata Steel has been decided to suspend all business travel (domestic travel on company business) with immediate effect as a measure of abundant precaution. The suspension of domestic travel - either by air, train or road - will remain effective till further notice.

A press communiqué issued by the company said: “The company has already announced the restrictions on overseas travel that will continue until further notice. Further, we are in the process of disabling the biometric system based attendance recording; only RFID based monitoring will be continued.

Tata Steel follows a robust management system framework and a sound safety governance structure that drives its health and safety measures.

We are constantly monitoring the COVID-19 situation across our locations and are also ensuring regular communication with our workforce. We have put in place several measures including increased precautions at our plants/offices and travel advisories to ensure the safety of our employees”.

Title: People with hypertension at higher risk of getting sick from Coronavirus: PGI doctors
Article:
Amid the chaos of the ongoing Coronavirus outbreak, health experts have warned that adults with underlying conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, and cancer are at highest risk for novel Coronavirus.

In India, where prevalence of hypertension is as high as 30 percent, physicians agree that there is a need for caution.

“People with hypertension are indeed at the higher risk of catching the Coronavirus (COVID-19),” said Dr Yash Paul Sharma, Professor and Head, Department of Cardiology, PGIMER.

Highlighting the data from a global research, Dr Sharma noted that Covid-19 patients with hypertension had fatality rate of 8.4 percent to 13.2 percent in those with cardiovascular disease, 9.2 percent with diabetes, 8 percent with chronic respiratory disease and 7.6 percent with cancer.

World Health Organisation (WHO) and Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have issued special warnings to safeguard those with chronic health conditions.

Also, a recent report in the China Daily stated that 50 percent of the 170 patients, who died in Wuhan in January, had hypertension or other NCDs (non-communicable diseases). Although such claims are yet to be clinically substantiated, a WHO-China joint mission on the COVID 19 outbreak has revealed similar findings. Top doctors from Wuhan, the ground zero of COVID-19 have also corroborated that almost 50 percent of those dying from the disease were hypertensive, said health experts.

With at least 35.7 percent people in Punjab suffering from raised blood pressure and a large majority unaware of their condition, screening and precautions to safeguard from the ongoing epidemic is more urgent than ever, the health experts say.

In Chandigarh, as many as 23.6 per cent of persons in the age group above 30 years screened under National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) were diagnosed with hypertension, while the number of patients diagnosed for diabetes was 16.5 per cent in a study conducted by UT Health Department in 2018.

Apart from this, a study by the Department of Endocrinology, PGIMER last year had indicated that Chandigarh could be the diabetic capital of India with 15 percent incidents of pre-diabetes and 40 percent of diabetes reported in the city.

Dr Sonu Goel, Professor, Department of Community Health and School of Public Health, PGIMER said that India reported its first case of death due to Coronavirus on Thursday.

Title: ‘Bhimbetka' staged at MP Tribal Museum
Article:
Play 'Bhimbetka' was staged at Madhya Pradesh Tribal Museum, here on Friday.

The poetic play 'Bhimbetka' was directed by Sanjay Shrotri, Hoshangabad.

The poetic drama 'Bhimbatka' focuses on the development of human civilization and the Mahabharata story or legend, reminiscent of characters like Bhima, Draupadi, Kunti, Duryodhana, Dharmaraja, etc. This poem also reminds us of the masters of freedom and its movements. is. Visions of the earth's past and destruction are seen in this poem. The poem presented is written by Mr. Vijay Bahadur Singh.

Located 13 km south east of Obedullaganj in Madhya Pradesh, this tourist destination is world famous for mural paintings (rock paintings). From this place the first people have been introduced to the common human civilization by Vishnu Sridhar Vakankar.

The tourist destination of the city has the history and ancient civilization of India within itself, it is the oldest and archaic pride.

Also, there is a mythological legend that Bhima has lived here with his brothers for some time during the period of exile in the Mahabharata period. Its history is very interesting and important. Which becomes very useful for the new generation and for their knowledge enhancement.

The poem boasts the importance of this oldest and archaeological and historical site within itself. The poem tells the gigantic history behind the caves and was beautifully performed by the artists on stage.

The poem also attempts to break the silence of human beings, pointing to the long history from the ancient period to the present and the efforts to preserve nature to avoid future storms.

Life should be not only for power and politics, but also for the next generation to do something and get recorded in history, its form should be positive which can be useful for someone.

Writer critic and poet Bahadur mentioned the botanical structure of the World Heritage Site, the zoological world, its rock paintings and the exile period of the Pandavas accumulated in folk life for centuries, the poet duly narrated the concerns surrounding the contemporary civilisation and their reasons.

Title: Furniture Show 2020 captivates shopaholics’ attention
Article:
A well-decorated home is a dream of everyone. The Furniture Show 2020 is captivating the attention of shopaholics.

This is the unique exhibition cum sale displaying various varieties of furniture in the city being put up at Gauhar Mahal. A ‘Furniture Show 2020’ is being organised by Handloom and Handicraft Development Corporation.

The furniture show 2020 is getting a good response by the visitors. The show began from March 11.

A well-furnished house always enchants the guests. Everybody loves to maintain the interiors of his house. Keeping this in view, a grand range of furniture for dining halls, drawing rooms, bed rooms and living rooms is displayed at the emporium. Besides, having a variety of indoor furniture the exhibition displays the furniture for the exteriors of the house.

There are varieties of sofa sets, dining tables, stools and corner tables of wood, bamboo and iron. Besides, the furniture collection also exhibits jute hammocks, wooden show pieces and other decorative pieces in glass and crystals.

Besides, to make the furniture show more magnificent the exhibition cum sale also exhibited the wooden and bamboo sculptures, wall hangings, wooden indoor and out door swings as well.

One can also find a variety of bed sheets, curtains and cushions in cotton, shimmer, bagh and linen. The prices of bamboo furniture begin from Rs 300 and went up to Rs 6,000. Similarly one could find the price of wooden, iron and glass furniture lowest from Rs 500 till Rs 8,000.

The furniture show is captivating the attention of the people and everyday sale goes upto Rs 50,000. The Bhopalites are taking pleasure to buy the various materials to decorate their houses.

Title: When humans continue ignoring nature’s lessons
Article:
One of the common features in most schools of philosophies and societies is that people down the centuries have learnt from observing Nature and learning lessons taught by it. Be it religion or science, lessons taught by nature are many and societies have benefited by adhering to these.It is not as if nature was teaching humans lessons only in the ancient times. Nature continues to give signs and teach us lessons but in recent decades, there has been a growing tendency to ignore the lessons and go for lip service. There are various examples of this proclivity in Uttarakhand, India and across the world.

The so called natural disaster during 2013 in Kedarnath caused the deaths of thousands of people in the region. The exact number of the dead is still not certain as many of the bodies were never recovered. Apart from other factors, one would have understood that many thousands of people gathering at once at this high Himalayan pilgrimage was the main reason for the large number of deaths.

But, ignoring this, we have pursued ‘ambitious’ plans to supposedly develop and secure this place to accommodate an even higher number of people. One of the major factors related to spirituality and religion especially in the Himalayas is peace and the lack of crowds. However, efforts have been made to maximise crowds in Kedarnath and other Himalayan shrines. Various safety measures have been incorporated using different engineering and technological aids. Granted that the pilgrimage is a source of income for those involved in related activities but have we learnt what nature tried to teach us in 2013?

At times, the effects of ignoring traditions based on such lessons are inconvenient but less dramatic. This was seen recently during the Assembly session in Gairsain. Here, though the Assembly building was supposedly built in the Pahadi style, the basics were evidently ignored.

While doors in Pahadi buildings are not high and generally may even have some awning of sorts above, the assembly building has a high entrance without any cover.

As a result, when it rained and snowed, a portion of the main foyer also became wet. The effects of ignoring other traditional and sensible practices which will be more inconvenient will become known in the not too distant future.

Coming to the subject that is spreading faster and wider than the disease itself- COVID-19, one would be amiss to ignore how here too the basics of nature were ignored in China and some other parts of the world too.

According to a news report, the coronavirus is suspected to have afflicted its first patient after the person consumed a pangolin or a bat carrying the virus. The extent of animal consumption in China is such that after the disease spread alarmingly in the nation, the Chinese government reportedly closed down 20,000 ‘wet markets’- places where wild animals are sold for consumption. Such places have animals, reptiles, birds and other creatures from different continents cramped in one place awaiting slaughter after capture and a stressful journey to reach the place where they meet a horrid end.

Even now, such wet markets exist in some nations despite the spread of COVID-19. Such practices cannot be excused in the name of culture alone in the present times. For those who do not believe in Karma, there is enough scientific evidence to show that such practices are harmful not only to the environment but also to the people indulging in them. And, Namaste instead of shaking hands is not the only aspect of Indian culture which can be adhered to for preventing such scenarios.

In all these instances, people have been ignoring the simple lessons that nature has been trying to teach them. Despite humans experiencing the power of nature in its intricate and raw forms, there is a proclivity to ignore this.

Such was not always the case, because most of our traditions and systems have been developed taking cognisance of such factors.

It now remains to be seen whether we will start taking such lessons seriously or continue in our foolish ways at our own peril.

Title: ‘Miss Gulab Jaan’ staged at Ravindra Bhavan
Article:
Marking the second day of 35th National Theatre Festival, the story of first female nautanki actress Gulab Jaan was presented. The Hindi play ‘Miss Gulab Jaan’ was staged at Ravindra Bhavan here on Friday, leaving the audience totally enthralled.

Miss Gulab Jaan was presented by Rang Vinayak Rangmandal theater repertory, Bareilly. The play was directed by Randhir Kumar and playwright by Asif from Chhapra Bihar, a NSD Alumni and recipient of Ustad Bismillah Khan Yuva award by Sangeet Natak Academy for his writings.

Based on the autobiography of Gulab Bai, the famous and first female artist in Nautanki that made her living legend, the play ‘Miss Gulab Jaan’ showcased the personal, professional and social conflicts in her life as an artist, a dalit woman, lover, wife, mother; a single woman in a profession dominated by men.

The play deals with personal, professional and social conflicts in her life, and makes everyone, especially an artist, realize how and what an artist goes through life.

Gulab Bai, popularly known as Gulab jaan, was an Indian stage performer of Nautanki the first female artist of the traditional operatic drama and considered by many as its pre-eminent exponent She was the founder of the Great Gulab

Theatre Company, a successful Nautanki troupe The Government of India awarded her the fourth highest civilian award of Padma Shri in 1990.

The play was beautifully presented. Light design and stage backdrop was wonderfully designed that added zest in the performance. Besides, the audience impressed the audience with their outstanding performances.

Title: Nath reviews preparations made for prevention of Corona Virus
Article:
Chief Minister Kamal Nath has instructed to declare holidays in schools and colleges to prevent the spread of Novel Corona Virus. The Chief Minister has said that the examination schedule will remain unchanged. Along with this, cinema halls should also be kept closed and there should be an attempt to stop all such events / programmes where a large number of people assemble.

Kamal Nath was reviewing the preparations made for the prevention of Novel Corona Virus in Mantralaya on Friday.

It was informed in the meeting that all possible steps have been taken for the safety of citizens in the State. Also, arrangements have been made to provide better treatment in case of an affected condition.

The Chief Minister said that the responsible citizens of all communities and religious gurus of different religions should also be urged to create awareness and not to organize such events in which people gather at one place. He said that our preparations should be such that the disease does not spread before the virus is detected.

He said that the steps taken in the country and abroad to prevent this and its better results should also be followed.

The Chief Minister also asked to screen people coming from the border states of Madhya Pradesh, especially Rajasthan, Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh.

He said that the preparations made for disease prevention by these states should also be studied. The Chief Minister sought the information about the preparations made so far by the Health and Medical Education Department.

Principal Secretary Public Health and Family Welfare Pallavi Jain Govil informed that 484 passengers were screened in the state on March 5, out of which 107 were in home isolation. A total of 690 passengers from 43 districts were screened, including 249 in Indore, Bhopal 122, Jabalpur 36, Gwalior 33, Ujjain 30 and Khargone 17.

Information and training was given to health officials of the state through the zoom platform and health workers like BCM, ANM, ASHA, ASHA assistants, supervisors, pharmacists etc. through satellite in connection with prevention of Novel Corona Virus.

It was informed that 348 isolation beds, 104 ventilators, 13115 PPE kits, 27,011 N-95 masks, 58 quarantine centres and 741 beds have been arranged for infected patients in the state.

Lab has been arranged in AIIMS Bhopal and NIRTH Jabalpur for Novel Corona virus test. A portal has been created for the information of this disease, the link of which is http://mphealthresponse.nhmmp.gov.in/covid/.

Control room has been created and call centre has been set up to provide information about infected and suspected patients. Control room no. is 0755-2527177. People are being made aware and informed about the symptoms of the disease through radio programmes, jingles and distribution of posters and pamphlets.

Additional Chief Secretary M Gopal Reddy, Principal Secretary Medical Education Sanjay Shukla, Secretary Public Relations P Narhari and senior officials of Medical Department were present in the meeting.

Title: House burgled, valuables taken away
Article:
Valuables worth Rs 1.5 lakh were stolen from sector -A area of Ayodhya Nagar police station on Thursday.

Police said the victim Umesh Kumar Singh lodged a complaint regarding burglary of gold and silver jewellery, Rs 10,000 cash and system of CCTV. In his complaint, the victim stated that he, along with his family, had gone to his village, Hatras, Uttar Pradesh, for celebrating Holi and when he returned on Thursday, he found locks of the door broken and on entering the house, silver and gold jewellery were found burgled.

The house was having CCTV camera and the burglers escaped with the camera fitted in the shop. The nearby houses, having cameras, would be investigated in the further investigation.

Based on the complaint, the police registered a case under sections 457 and 380 of the IPC.

The victim works for the Woman and Children Welfare Department. Police said that the miscreants escaped with DVR which was done to evade identification.The victim, along with his family, left the house on March 7 for celebrating Holi and when he returned on March 12, the valuables were found burgled.

In the burglary, expensive clothes were also burgled. The almirah having the valuables were targeted which raises suspicion that they were aware of the valuables in the house and had already done the recce of the area and targeted the house.

Meanwhile, valuables worth Rs 2 lakh were burgled from New Ashoka Garden area on Thursday. The victim, Khetpal Singh, had gone to Agra on March 9 and when he returned on Thursday, gold ornaments were found burgled.

Two gold chains, two pair gold ear rings, six gold finger rings were burgled. The victim is posted as a head constable in 13th Battalion SAF.

Title: Namaste best way to greet: Rawat
Article:
The Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat has advocated use of the traditional Indian method of greeting, ‘Namaste’ to prevent spread of Coronavirus.

He said that shaking hands and hugging should be avoided these days. “Let us say Namaste or Jai Hind or Jai Badri Vishal while greeting each other. these are the most scientific and safe methods of greeting,’’ he said.

Title: Health services pathetic in State, says Congress
Article:
The vice president of Uttarakhand Congress party, Surya Kant Dhasmana has said that the health services of the state are pathetic. He said that the fact that the dead foetus of a woman was removed after nine days by doctors at Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) hospital underlies the status of health services in the state.

On the intervention of Dhasmana and others the doctors of GDMC operated on the pregnant woman of Dichali village near Chinyalisaur in Uttarkashi district on Friday and removed the dead foetus. The doctors of the hospital had earlier asked to the relatives of the woman to shift her to higher centre. The woman was referred from Uttarkashi hospital to Dehradun on March 3 and on March 4, she was admitted in GDMC hospital. The relatives of the woman allege that the doctors knew from day one that the child in her womb has died but they didn’t undertook operation.

On March 12, the doctors directed the woman to shift to a higher centre following which the relatives protested. When the Congress leader Dhasmana came to know about the issue, he arrived in the hospital and expressed anger at the apathy of the hospital authorities.

Dhasmana told the Pioneer that he contacted the Principal Ashutosh Sayana, the medical superintendent and the district magistrate and expressed deep anguish on the incident. “ I demanded that the woman should be operated without delay. Finally the operation was done at 11.30 am and the dead foetus was removed. The woman has been shifted to ward,’’ he said. The Congress leader claimed that one Khemraj Singh of Nagrasu in Chamoli district also met him in the hospital and narrated his sordid story. “ On March 6, wife of Khemraj Singh delivered a baby on March 9 at GDMC hospital.

The doctors asked Khemrah that since the ventilator in the hospital is occupied, he should shift his child to another hospital. The child was taken to a private nursing home where the child died,’’ Dhasmana said. The Congress leader claimed that the relatives of many patients complained about gross negligence, corruption and rude behaviour of staff during his visit to the hospital. He warned that the hospital authorities would face wrath of people if things are not improved.

Title: BSL suspends biometric attendance system till 31st March
Article:
Biometric attendance system has been suspended at Bokaro Steel Plant (BSL) in a precautionary measure to avoid the risk of infection of coronavirus (COVID -19) through contact till 31 March.

Plant management issued a circular in this concern on Thursday with an instruction of its employees to mark their attendance in manually in registers till 31 March, informed RK Tripathi Manager Biometric division of BSL. Notably, the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared the outbreak of coronavirus a public health emergency an international concern on 30 January.

Later the Supreme Court of India suspended the biometric attendance system and introduced their attendance system manually in the attendance register, said an official. The infection of COVID-19 is a contagious disease and people can get infected by touching the communicated surface or objects, he said. The total confirmed cases of coronavirus have touched 73 in India while one death is reported due to its infection.

Taking precautionary measures India Government has decided to quarantine itself from the rest of the world, suspending all visas, except those issued for diplomatic, official, UN-international organisations, employment and projects till 15 April, said an official.

Title: New flag pole raised after glitch in noon
Article:
A portion of the 105 feet high new flag pole being hoisted at the historical Jhanda Mela broke down when it was nearly raised here on Friday. According to the police, eight persons were injured when a part of the wooden flag pole fell on them.

According to the management committee, it is being surmised that the consistent rain weakened the lower portion of the flag pole, causing it to crack.The Jhanda Mela began with religious fervour and enthusiasm as thousands gathered here on Friday morning. After various rituals during the day, the ritual raising of the new flag pole began at about 3 PM. As the flag pole was nearly raise, it broke from the lower portion due to which the part almost raised fell on the devotees standing below. The injured were taken by 108 ambulance service to the Mahant Indiresh hospital. The accident caused panic among the multitudes gathered on the occasion.

However, the police under the superintendent of police (City) Shweta Choubey handled the situation efficiently, controlling the crowds. The devotees were sent out of the Mela site towards Saharanpur Chowk and the injured were transported to the hospital.

Later, under the directions of the Mahant Devendra Dass, the devotees enthusiastically raise the flag pole at about 6:40 PM.

Earlier, during the morning, the rain could not dampen the enthusiasm of the devotees who gathered in multitudes to participate in the historic occasion. The old flag pole was lowered after which the new flag pole was ceremoniously bathed in holy items. After that, the various covers were put on the new flag pole.

Later in the evening after the successful raising of the new flag pole, the Mahant greeted the devotees and all people of the State on the occasion. He said that the Jhanda Mela sends the message of love, harmony and peace for all. Those who pay obeisance here have their wishes fulfilled. This is the reason why the faith of devotees in Jhanda Sahib has been growing stronger, he added. It is pertinent to mention here that apart from the locals, devotees from Uttar Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, Himachal Pradesh and even some foreign nations were present in the Jhanda Mela on Friday.

Title: Rain, hail and snowfall forecast again in State today
Article:
Spells of rain and hail were experienced in the provisional state capital Dehradun and other parts of the state on Friday. According to the state meteorological centre, similar conditions are likely to be experienced in various parts of the state on Saturday as well.

People in Dehradun woke up on Friday to rain and hail. Similar weather was experienced in Nainital and some other parts of the state too. According to the forecast issued by the state meteorological centre on Friday evening, the state is likely to experience partly to generally cloudy sky with light to moderate rain/thunderstorm/snowfall likely to occur at a many places in the state on Saturday. Snowfall is likely to occur at places situated at altitude of 2,500 metres and above. The meteorological centre has also issued a warning about the possibility of hail/lightening at isolated places in Dehradun, Haridwar, Nainital and Udham Singh Nagar districts of the state.

Dehradun is forecast to experience partly to generally cloudy sky with rain/thunderstorm accompanied with hail/lightening likely to occur. The maximum and minimum temperatures in the provisional state capital are likely to be around 21 degree Celsius and and 11 degrees Celsius respectively on Saturday. Meanwhile, the maximum and minimum temperatures reported in various places of the state were 18.5 degrees Celsius and 13.4 degrees Celsius respectively in Dehradun, 25.6 degrees Celsius and 16.8 degree Celsius in Pantnagar, 9.5 degrees Celsius and 4.3 degrees Celsius in Mukteshwar and eight degrees Celsius and six degrees Celsius respectively in New Tehri.

Title: MGM rape case rocks Assembly, Govt forms probe committee
Article:
The Jamshedpur gang rape incident rocked the Assembly on Friday with the Opposition alleging that the law and order situation in the State had deteriorated under the JMM-Congress Government. As per reports, a 50 year old woman patient was allegedly gang raped in Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MGM) Hospital, Jamshedpur. The matter came to light when the Sakchi police produced the victim in court for registering her statement under section 164 of IPC. The police have even carried out the medical test of the victim but the report is yet to come.

The woman in her statement before police had said that on March 6 she was admitted at ward number 64 of MGM when a youth under the influence of alcohol assaulted and raped her. As the incident has occurred at State health minister Banna Gupta’s constituency, the incident has given a tool in the hand of Opposition BJP to attack BJP over poor law and order situation.

BJP legislator from Rajmahal Anant Ojha raising the issue demanded work adjournment on the issue. Ojha said, “It is very shameful incident that a woman who is admitted at prestigious hospital is raped. The incident becomes more shocking as it has occurred at the home constituency of health minister Banna Gupta.”

The Health Minister intervening on the issue said that City SP is investigating the case. He said, “Strict action will be taken against those found behind the incident.” However, the BJP legislators dissatisfied with Minister’s remark entered the well of the House staging protest over the incident. The BJP lawmakers demanded constitution of probe committee in the incident. Later parliamentary affairs minister Alamgir Alam said, “The government has constituted a committee to probe the incident.” Later on Speaker intervention the matter was sorted out.

Like Thursday the House resumed with Speaker carrying out question hour, zero hour and other proceedings of house. CPI (ML) MLA from Bagodar Vinod Kumar Singh raised the issue of power cuts at DVC command area. He said that there are severe power cuts in State especially in the districts such as Hazaribagh, Bokaro, Giridih, Koderma and others which fall under the command area of Damodar valley Corporation (DVC).

BJP legislator Amar Bauri said that police is treating Baghmara MLA Dhullu Mahto as terrorist. The government should consider that he is people’s representative. Bauri said, “Police are after Dhullu Mahto as if he is murder accused or involved in terrorist activities.” Due to police action, Dhullu Mahto is unable to attend House proceedings. The BJP lawmaker demanded Speaker’s protection to Mahto in this case. On Dhullu Mahto case even State BJP president Deepak Prakash had said that police is treating Mahto as criminal and terrorist. The Baghmara MLA who is absconding is facing charges of land-grabbing, molestation and extortion.

Mahto is a two-time legislator, and he managed to retain his Baghmara seat despite an anti-incumbency wave in Jharkhand during the 2019 Assembly polls.

Title: Govt suspends ‘Sarkar Aapke Dwar’ till April 15
Article:
State Government has suspended the popular ‘Sarkar Aapkey Dwar’ programme in all districts till April 15 in the wake of alertness towards Coronavirus. Holding a video conferencing here on Friday with DCs and senior officials Chief Secretary Dr DK Tiwari asked DCs of all districts to suspend the bi-weekly programme as a precautionary measure till April 15.

The Chief Secretary said that the effect of coronavirus is increasing all over the world. So far 117 countries have been hit by it. In some parts of the country, people affected by it have been found, but eastern India is still almost untouched by it. In this situation, vigilance is necessary. He asked to ban such gatherings, in which outsiders can participate and only such events can be allowed, in which locals would participate.

The CS instructed all the Deputy Commissioners regarding the corona virus, that they should not allow it to become a scary thing. “Ensure that the correct information reaches common masses. Also, keep an eye on the rumours and make the public aware about the prevention and precaution of this disease,” he said.

Dr Tiwari said that information should not be circulated until it is medically clear that a person is affected by Coronavirus. At the same time, instructing to keep all preparations to deal with any situation, said that all the crowded places should give information related to the corona rescue through banners, posters and hoardings.

The Chief Secretary instructed to take measures to prevent the spread of Coronavirus to as many people as possible, and said that cleanliness is important in the prevention of this disease. He instructed all the DCs to focus on cleanliness, especially in the municipal area. At the same time, he directed to hold meetings with social organisations for awareness and to conduct gram sabha at panchayat level.

Also, as part of the preparation, it has been directed to make an isolation ward of five beds in every district hospital and 8-10 beds in medical colleges as soon as possible. At the same time, he also directed about training to be held in the district on March 20 to look after the potential of corona infection. He said that mock drills should also be done under preparation.

In any case, one should not get upset about an infected person. He said that the need to apply masks is not to everyone, but only to the infected person and the medical staff involved in their treatment.

The CS said that on the basis of doubt, 19 people of Jharkhand have been sampled. The investigation report of 17 of them turned out to be negative. The investigation report of two samples is yet to come. He said that earlier the investigation of the samples was being done outside the State, but now arrangements have also been made to the MGM Hospital in Jamshedpur.

Additional Chief Secretary Indu Shekhar Chaturvedi, Principal Secretary AP Singh, Nitin Madan Kulkarni, Secretary Rahul Sharma, Praveen Toppo, KK Soan, Amitabh alongwith other officials were present in the meeting.

Title: Public gathering venues to remain suspended till Mar 31
Article:
nAs part of advisory issued by Government of India, after the closure of schools, colleges and universities across the state to control the spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19), now state government has declared the closure of public library, swimming pool and water parks till March 31 with immediate effect.

As per the earlier advisory issued, state government school and higher education department has declared closure of schools, colleges (both government and private) and universities (both government and private) till March 31, from Friday (March 13).

Similarly, the urban administration department secretary Alarmelmangai D in a letter issued to all the district collectors, Municipal Corporation Commissioners and Municipal Council-Nagar Panchayat Chief Executive Officers issued the directive to close all the public libraries, government, semi-government and private gymnasiums (gyms), swimming pools and water parks within limits of urban bodies.

The letter further directs to ensure stern implementation of the directive and submit the action taken report.

Additional to it, all the anganbadi and mini-anganbadi of state will remain closed till March 31 with immediate effect. During this period, the beneficiaries will be distributed ready-to-eat food without fail.

The weight festival and ‘Poshan Abhiyan’, the fortnight programmes will continue to be suspended till next order.

Women and child development department secretary Siddarth Komal Pardeshi, in a circular to departmental commissioner, all divisional commissioners, collectors, district programme officers and child development project officers of state have directed to ensure the implementation of the order.

In compliance with the Central Government’s advisory, state government has decided to close down all the aanganbadi centers and mini aanganbadi centers of the state till March 31, 2020 for prevention and control of corona virus infection (COVID-19).

In this duration, beneficiaries will be provided ready-to-eat foods as per the provisions. Vazan Tyohar and Poshan Pakhwada programmes have been postponed until further notice. Secretary Women and Child Development Depatrment Sidhartha Komal Singh Pardeshi has issued circular from mantralaya to department commissioner, all the divisional commissioners, collectors, district programme officers and child development project officials.

Skill Development, all the government and private institutions and training centers under Technical Education and Employment Department will also remain closed till March 31, 2020.

Additional Chief Secretary of Skill Development, Technical Education and Employment Department Renu Pillai has issued a letter with necessary guidelines for prevention and control of corona virus, to Director Technical Education, Director Employment and Training, CEO Chhattisgarh State Skill Development Authority- Livelihood College Project Raipur, Registrar Chhattisgarh Swami Vivekananda Technical University Bhilai and principals of all the engineering colleges, polytechic institutions, pharmacy institutes and architechture institutes. It is stated in the letter that the examinations scheduled in this duration will be conducted as per the schedule. Appointed staff will have to make proper arrangements for the examinations. It is mentioned in the letter that all the instructions should be strictly complied with.

In compliance with the advisory, all the government and private universities and colleges in Chhattisgarh too have been closed with immediate effect till March 31. Annual examinations scheduled in this duration will be conducted as per the time-table. Commissioner, Directorate of Higher Education has issued circular in the context to registrars of government and private universities and principals of government and private colleges.

Title: Jumbos return to Dalma sanctuary from Bengal jungles
Article:
The picturesque Dalma Wildlife Sanctuary is abuzz with activities of over 100 jumbos these days. After staying in Bengal jungles for almost a year, the elephants have started returning to their Dalma home.

All the 130-odd jumbos are finally back home after their annual sojourn to the jungles of West Mindnapore and Bankura in neighbouring Bengal.

A forest official said several tourists are attracted towards as besides the flora and fauna, people also visit the sanctuary to watch elephants. It is the best time to spend time at the elephant abode.

“The elephants can be seen indulging in activities near the watering holes. The tuskers give visitors a reason to cheer. They can also use the hideouts built the watering holes,” the official informed.

Dalma range officer (West) Dinesh Chandra said some of the jumbos have moved uphill while some were still anchored on the foothills. “We have asked village youths recruited as daily wagers to keep a tab on movement of animals have been asked to be alert and asked to report about elephants near human habitat,” he added.

Officials of Dalma informed that over a dozen have come back while others are on their way. Others are expected to leave Mednipore and Bankura jungles shortly.

Abundance of water and fodder had held up jumbos in forest of neighbouring Bengal. Jumbos generally return home to the reserve by the end of February or at the most the first week of March. But this year they overstayed in Bengal.

The perennial water sources are basically ponds running 15 to 20 feet deep while the new artificial water sources are similar to the lake with adequate slope area across the lake for easy access of the wildlife to the water source. The depth of the artificial water sources is also around 15 feet.

Notably Dalma is the best elephant habitat of Jharkhand, where the pachyderms love to spend their summer. Dalma used to be pleasing with temperatures less than 30 degrees C. But due to rising mercury over the years the elephants started migration to green pastures.

The measures taken by the forest department include availability of adequate water holes, salt licks and sufficient food for the tuskers. But these are not enough for all the elephants residing in the area. He said perennial water sources in the Dalma forest range have been for long catering to the water need of the tuskers but owing to the rising temperature several of the water sources got dried up which led the department to initiate the work on large scale.

Title: Congress cancels Dehradun protest march
Article:
The opposition Congress party has decided to cancel its proposed rally in Dehradun on March 18 due to the threat posed by the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). The party was planning to hold a massive rally in Dehradun on March 18 against what it termed anti people polices of the incumbent BJP government. On the day, the Trivendra Singh Rawat led BJP government is completing three years in office.

The Uttarakhand government has decided to hold programmes in all the 70 assembly constituencies of the state to commemorate three years in office of Trivendra Singh Rawat government.

The spokesperson of the Uttarakhand Congress Garima Dasauni said that the Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) president, Pritam Singh had directed that the rally should be cancelled as the threat caused by the dreaded Coronavirus is increasing continuously.

She said that the PCC president felt that the Congress being a responsible party has decided not to hold the rally as a precautionary measure.

The Coronavirus has been declared as pandemic by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and one patient in India has succumbed to the disease.

Title: Citizen woes increase due to strike of Govt employees
Article:
The public of Dehradun are facing problems due to the indefinite strike of the members of Uttarakhand General-OBC Employees Association.

According to some locals, the State Government is responsible for the absence of employees from the various government offices which is causing considerable inconvenience to the citizens.

The strike of the General-OBC employees in the State has been going on for more than 10 days now, which has begun to have an adverse effect on the lives of people.

According to a Rajpur resident Karan Chandela, “I have visited the Regional Transport Office (RTO) thrice in one week but still could not get a learner’s license for a bike. In the online application, they are giving date and time but there was negligible staff in the office. There were many fellows like me who were there for hours but nothing could happen due to the absence of the staff.” “Due to the strike, the submission of some of my documents to complete the procedure of getting the pension in the Social Welfare Department is stuck for the past one week. Every time I reach their office, there are more common people and a handful of staff members.

I am a widow and have two daughters and leaving them alone at home every day just to submit few documents is not possible for me.

Last week I came at least twice a day for three days but failed to deposit the documents. I do not know when the employees will stop the strike,” said Deepa Pannu, a resident of Jakhan.

According to a Dalanwala resident Manglesh Sharma, “I waited for four hours in the office of Education Directorate to get my work done. The government should really do something about the strike of the employees.”

However, some of the people consider the State government responsible for their trouble in the government offices due to the strike of general-OBC employees.

According to them, the inability of the government to take a fair decision without delay is the reason behind the absence of employees in the State.

“Had the government declared that the promotions will be given on merits rather than reservations, the employees would have returned to their work sooner.

If somebody less worthy than me would get the promotion just because he/she belongs to a particular caste then I’ll fight for my rights too.

The government is just busy playing vote bank politics,” said a school teacher Umed Naithani.

Title: Tourist claims hearing feeble roar of tigress in Betla Park
Article:
A tourist’s version of feeble roar in National Park Betla resurrects the ghost of the tigress while IG NTCA ( inspector general national tiger conservation authority ) Assam region under which comes Jharkhand’s Palamu tiger reserve W Longvah is to reach National Park Betla soon.

Giving this information DS Srivastava secretary of Nature Conservation Society said, “IG NTCA Longvah telephoned me and said he would be very soon coming over to National Park Betla. I understand the death of a tigress there in the park is the prime reason of the IG to come over here but it is now almost a month the big cat died.”

The tigress was found dead near road number 2 of this park on the night of February 15, which was cremated on February 16 after a due and elaborate postmortem of the corpse carried out by a team of 5 vet doctors. Srivastava said, “I would urge IG Longvah to speak to the tourist Saibal Roy who has claimed to have heard the sigh and moaning of a tiger or tigress near road number 2 of the park in the evening say between 5 to 5.10 PM on February 15 in the evening and the same night after hours of sighing she was found dead.” The Pioneer reached the Debjani hotel in Betla where Saibal Roy the tourist had checked in on February 15 with six others also.

Speaking to the Pioneer Saibal Roy the tourist said on phone, “ I along with my fellow tourists was in a jeep near road number 2 of the park when I heard a feeble roar of a tiger or tigress, which appeared to be in utter distress and discomfort.” Roy said he was in Betla on February 15 and three days later February 18 he and his team moved out from the PTR. Roy said he is a wildlife photographer and spends time in the jungles and as such knows the sound/voice of wildlife more.He further said, “We stopped there. We found a herd of bison there in utter confusion. The bison gets into confusion when they see any tiger or tigress. Here the herd of the bison was behaving the same way.”Asked if he or any of his fellow tourists saw the tigress/ tiger Roy said “No, none of us.”

The driver Najibullah said, “ When Roy Saheb and his team stopped near the site where was coming the roar in distress the monkeys, the deer and the peacocks were sending out alarm signals a feature these animals do when a tiger or a tigress is around.”

Srivastava here raised a pointer, “A tourist heard the feeble roar in the evening of February 15 between 5 to 5.10 PM but where the tiger trackers, tiger strike force, trackers , forest guards etc were in the park as none of them heard this roar at all but discovered the wild life only dead and kept guarding the dead.”

Srivastava further lobbed a query, “Was this tigress properly and adequately trailed or monitored by the ground staff or was she left to fend for herself? How is it that no ground staff had any inkling of this tigress in distress while a tourist of Kolkata found and claimed he heard roars, which were of distress and discomfort?”

The driver told, There was a talk doing the rounds here that there is a tigress here in the park that is pregnant and so Roy ji and other tourists. thought the distress roar is related to delivery of litter of cubs but there was no such thing at all.

A noted vet doctor Ajay who was one of the 5 doctors who had conducted the post mortem of the tigress had said, “There was no question of this tigress ever remaining any pregnant.”

He said “I would exhort IG NTCA Longvah to take the versions of the tourist Roy as this will expose the gap between the PTR’s official report & ground report.”

Title: Govt postpones March 18 events in Assembly constituencies
Article:
In view of the precautions being observed considering the spread of novel coronavirus, the State Government has postponed the programmes to be held in all the Vidhan Sabha constituencies to mark the state government’s completion of three years in office on March 18.

In a communication sent by the chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh to all the district magistrates, it has been stated that the programme Vikas Ke Teen Saal “Bate Kam- Kaam Zyada” was to be held in all the Vidhan Sabha constituencies on March 18 to mark three years of the State government in office.

However, novel coronavirus is spreading in the world like a disaster and new cases of infected persons are also being identified in some Indian states. Considering this, the programme proposed to be held on March 18 is being postponed till further orders, stated Singh.

It is pertinent to mention here that this is the fourth major event either postponed or cancelled in the State. Earlier, the State Government had postponed the Adventure Summit scheduled to be heldat Ramnagar during March and the Wellness Summit scheduled to be held in Dehradun during April.

The State’s governor Baby Rani Maurya also cancelled the annual spring festival Vasantotsav to be held at the Raj Bhawan this month.

It will be recalled that the programmes which were to be held in all the 70 Vidhan Sabha constituencies of the state on March 18 were to focus on the achievements of the State Government under Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat during its three years in office so far.

With the respective MLAs as the chief guests, the events were also meant to spread information about the various public welfare initiatives and schemes being undertaken by the State Government.

Title: Gyan Jyoti Scheme alumni encouraged by BSL
Article:
Nine students of the first batch of Birhor tribe under Gyan Jyoti Yojana operated under CSR of Bokaro Steel Plant had completed ITI training in the year 2014 after completing Matriculation and Plus Two. Out of these, four students have already got employment in prestigious institutes on the basis of their merit, while the remaining five students are currently preparing for various competitive examinations.

Under a programme organised to guide and encourage them Mukul Prasad, Executive Director (Personnel and Administration) of BSL presented books and other useful material. On this occasion, Executive Director (MM) VK Pandey, Executive Director (Finance & Accounts) DK Saha, Chief General Manager (Municipal Administration) Vibhakar, General Manager (HAD) Neeta Ba, Chief of communication Manikant Dhan, Deputy General Manager (CSR) CRK Sudhanshu were present.

It is noteworthy that under this scheme, BSL adopted the children of Birhor tribe and made them study up to plus 2 free of cost and also made free arrangements for their living, eating, drinking, uniforms etc. 9 students of the first batch later completed ITI under thus scheme.

Title: Amit Shah to reach AIIMS, Rishikesh today
Article:
The Union Home Minister Amit Shah is slated to arrive in Rishikesh to attend the second convocation of the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) on Saturday. On Friday, in the presence of Garhwal inspector general Ajay Rautela, the deputy inspector general and Dehradun senior superintendent of police, Arun Mohan Joshi conducting a briefing regarding the security arrangements at the main programme venue- AIIMS Rishikesh.

The security arrangements were reviewed and considering the present scenario, all the officers and personnel were directed to remain alert and discharge their responsibilities diligently.Rautela and Joshi directed all the members of the police force deployed for security at the site that they should reach their designated place for the VIP duty on time. They should receive information about their duty and check their surroundings properly.

The senior officer concerned should be informed immediately in case any suspicious object is found to be at the site. Only authorised persons and people with valid pass and their vehicles will be allowed entry at the programme venue.

An alert eye should be maintained from the security point of view also on those persons who are to meet the Union Home Minister. Only those persons who have been listed in advance should be allowed entry after the requisite anti-sabotage checking, the senior officers stressed. They warned the personnel that they should neither use their mobile phone while on duty nor leave their duty point without informing the officer concerned. Strict action will be taken against any officer or personnel found to be negligent while on duty, the senior officers warned. All the nodal police officers were directed to identify all the police officers and personnel in uniform and plain clothes who will be deployed with them.

Their duty cards should be checked and they should be briefed properly about their designated duties. It should be ensured that the officers and personnel should not leave their duty spot to gather at one spot.

The in-charge of the route to be taken by the VIPs were directed to ensure that there is no construction material or other objects on the route to be taken by the motorcade which may cause any obstruction in movement.

At sites which experience more pressure of traffic and crowd, barricades and caution tapes should be used to bar the traffic before the main road to control the situation.

Title: Chhattisgarh assembly to resume on March 26
Article:
nChhattisgarh Legislative Assembly has extended its ongoing holidays till March 25 as a preventive measure following coronavirus scare spreading fast across the country.

The ongoing budget session of the assembly was scheduled to reassemble on March 16 after Holi holidays. A meeting of the Business Advisory Committee was held in the Chhattisgarh Legislative Assembly on Friday morning.

The committee decided to extend the holidays till March 25. The session will now remain suspended till March 24.

“In the meeting, it was decided to postpone the proceedings of the Vidhan Sabha in view of the prevailing situation,” Chief Minister and the leader of the House Bhupesh Baghel said.

Different advisories have been issued in the country regarding Corona, they have also issued orders regarding this in the state, he said, adding that school, colleges have been closed and they were following the guidelines issued by the Central Government.

The Chief Minister added that the state government would take further decision reviewing the situation. He said though the decisions of the meeting of the Business Advisory Committee were generally made public in the House, but he was sharing it publicly as the situation today was different.

Title: Baghel dedicates modern ropeway at Dongargarh temple
Article:
nChief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Friday dedicated to the public newly constructed modern ropeway at Chhirpani premises in Bamleshwari temple, Dongargarh.

He also prayed at the temple on the occasion of Rang Panchami for progress and prosperity of the state populace.

Speaking on this occasion, Chief Minister said “the temple already had one ropeway and with inauguration of second one the people will be benefitted a lot and tourism will also increased. Lakhs of devotees reach the temple and the inauguration of the new ropeway will ease their trouble”, he added.

“It will help the elderly persons and differently abled to climb the hillock with ease ,” he further added.

Ministers Tamradhwaj Sahu and Mohammad Akbar were also present on this occasion.

Title: BJP blames Govt for power crisis
Article:
State BJP on Friday blamed the incumbent Govt for power crisis in the State. State BJP Spokesperson Pratul Shahdeo said when the BJP government was formed in the State then also the problem of huge amounts of power dues of DVC had surfaced. “In the year 2016 the Govt had paid an amount of Rs 4500 crores to DVC after a meeting at the Union Energy Minister. This amount included the dues of the 14 month long Govet led by Hemant Soren. Also, the BJP government was paying Rs 100 crore on an average every month to DVC,” he said.

Shahdeo said, “Hemant Govt had stopped all payments as soon as it came to power. This included the monthly dues of DVC. Despite repeated warnings of DVC the Hemant Govt did not start payments to DVC. On the contrary the stopped payments of contractors of building construction and road construction were started after liaisoning with them. The Cong and the Govt are diverting the attention of the people by cursing the old government for the current power crisis. They should resolve the issue without any delay. Blaming the old Govt for everything is petty politics.”

Title: Workshop on cleanliness, food and nutrition held
Article:
Food and Nutrition Board, Government of India in collaboration with Ranchi based NGO Samvedna, organised a day long workshop at Suchna Bhawan as a part of the cleanliness fortnight being observed from March 1 to March 15 in the State capital.

The Chief Guest for the occasion was Shivdhari Ram, Chairman State SC/ST Commission, Government of Jharkhand. Ravindra Gaurav, President Samvedna, Subhrapratim Dey, In Charge Food & Nutrition Board, Government of India, Ranchi, Dr Raman Ballabh Senior Resource Person- IICA Ministry of Corporate Affairs and Mitul Nayak, Technical Specialist, Child Health and Nutrition, World Vision India were present. Teachers and principals from various schools of the district were also present for the workshop.

Addressing a press conference, Ram said that that it was Gandhiji who was a great advocate of cleanliness. “Gandhiji started the drive alone and gradually the entire country followedhim. Just like that an individual must take the initiative of keeping the surroundings clean and set an example for others to follow. Women play a vital role in this as they are the first teachers in a child’s life. Children should be taught about the importance of cleanliness right from a very young age at home and also at school.”

“Everyone bothers to keep their homes clean but it is also equally important to keep the surroundings and locality clean.

People generally only want to talk and blame each other but now is the right time to take the plunge and make a change,” added Ram.

A technical session on environmental sanitation and nutrition was conducted by Dr Raman Ballabhin where he emphasised on eating fresh fruits and vegetables on a daily basis. “Different colours of fruits and vegetables should be made a part of all meals. Whole grains like jawar and bajra should be preferred over rotis made of maida. Peanuts, chicken, daal and walnuts are rich sources of protein and should be included. Plastic and thermocol plates used at functions and gatherings should be avoided as they are harmful not only for the human body but the environment as well.”

Mitul Nayak spoke on the importance of personal hygiene and nutrition. “It is imperative to maintain personal hygiene by one and al. It is also equally important to keep the surroundings near houses and schools clean. A healthy and balanced diet is essential to fight malnutrition. A balanced diet should comprise of carbohydrates, fat, proteins and vitamins in adequate quantities. Green leafy vegetables and fruits are rich in vitamins which should certainly be included in one’s daily diet.”

Title: Prolonged power cut hits production, business
Article:
Amidst growing concerns over the coronavirus that hit the global markets, prolonged power cuts crippled lives, severely hit production activities and affected the industrial belt located in the outskirts the Bokaro city.

Most of the small and medium industrial units could not start production due to frequent power cuts during the past seven days.

Continued power outages since past seven-eight days across the district is adversely affecting the domestic industrial production, said Pappu Choubey an industrialist of Bokaro Industrial Area Development Authority (BIADA) at Balidih. “According to an estimate, a 24 hours power cuts incurs a loss of approximately Rs 10 crore, and pushes back the progress by two months,” added Choubey.

The erratic power supply also affected businesses, which may fall by 60 per cent in the past day, said Anand a shop owner at Chas. “Now we will have to depend on power generators and investors,” he added. Power cuts have not only affected the production and business but the absence of continuous supply has had an adverse impact on the study of the school-going children. Now board exams for Class 10 and 12 students are on, students are finding very hard time, said Vinod a resident of Sector 2 in Bokaro City.

Meanwhile, excessive use of diesel generators has also burnt a hole in the pockets of the businessmen owing to the high cost of fuel, said Alok a shopkeeper of City Center sector 4 in Bokaro.

Power crisis erupted as Damodar Valley Corporation (DVC) has begun power supply rationing to realise dues worth Rs 4,995 crore from Jharkhand Bijli Vitran Nigam Limited (JBVNL). Since February 28, DVC has been cutting 50 per cent power it used to supply to JBVNL daily which hit Dhanbad, Giridih, Bokaro, Ranchi, Koderma, Hazaribagh and East Singhbhum areas.

Official sources said that DVC had issued a notice (on 11 February) informing to JBVNL about the power cut from 26 February 26 if failed to clear its dues before 25 February.

Title: Jharkhand gets 15 rurban clusters with city like facilities
Article:
In the race for development, the rural areas should not be left behind from the cities, the rural areas should also have facilities like the cities, with this objective, the Narendra Modi government has started the Shyama Prasad Rurban Mission. Jharkhand has been allocated 15 clusters under this mission. The Minister of Rural Development, Government of India, Narendra Singh Tomar gave this information while answering a question of Mahesh Poddar, MP in Rajya Sabha on Friday.

Tomar informed that the objective of Shyama Prasad Mukherjee Rurban Mission (SPMRM) is to build 300 Rurban clusters across the country. The mission aims to bridge the gap between rural and urban areas by providing urban amenities in rural areas. Out of these 300 clusters included in SPMRM, 296 clusters from 28 states and 8 union territories have been identified and approved. 288 Integrated Action Plans (ICAPs) have been approved for 28 states and 7 union territories, defining the broad framework of development of each cluster. Additionally, the Detailed Project Report (DPR) of 248 clusters has been approved by the respective State Level Empowered Committees (SLEC).

Under SPMRM, 15 clusters have been allocated to the state of Jharkhand. The ICAP of all these clusters has been approved by the Ministry. The total outlay of this mission is 5142.08 crores.

Title: Industry growth slips from 33.2% to 5.9%
Article:
The growth rate in the industry sector in the State has been decreasing for the last four years due to the slowdown in global economy, fall in manufacturing and construction activities, mining sector slowdown and problems in the power and industry sectors.

Industries Minister Dibya Sahankar Mishra informed this in the State Assembly in response to a question of BJD member Soumya Ranjan Patnaik on Friday.

While the growth rate in the industry sector was 33.2 per cent in 2016-17, it came down to 8.6 per cent in 2017-18 and 6.7 per cent in 2018-19 and it is expected to be 5.9 per cent in 2019-20, according to the Economic Survey.

The Minister said that increase in industry growth rate basically depends on the growth in five sectors such as mining and quarrying, manufacturing, electricity, gas and water supply and construction.
