While the mining and quarrying sector growth rate decreased from 13.74 per cent in 2016-17 to 3.38 per cent tin 2017-18, the manufacturing sector growth rate slipped from 33.17 per cent in 2016-17 to 5.92 per cent in 2018-19.

The growth rate in the electricity, gas and water supply sectors has also remained irregular during the last two years as they depend on mining activities.

Title: 328 coastal villages in State to be tsunami-ready
Article:
The Odisha Disaster Management Authority (OSDMA) is now on its way to achieve ‘tsunami-ready tag’ for 328 vulnerable villages of six costal districts.

The capacity building activities to the vulnerable villages would be expanded and the tag would be achieved by fulfilling the 11 parameters set by the Unicef.

Already two villages, namely Baxipali of Ganjam district and Gadaharishpur of Jagatsingpur district have qualified all the parameters. These two villages might get Unicef certificate soon.

After award of the certificate, the two villages would be first tsunami ready villages among 56 nations in the entire Indian Ocean region.

This was discussed in the Governing Body meeting of the OSDMA held here on Friday under the chairmanship of Chief Secretary Asit Tripathy wherein Additional Chief Secretary OSDMA Pradeep Kumar Jena outlined the issues for discussion.

Reviewing the updates for management of natural disasters, Chief Secretary Tripathy directed for proper repair and maintenance of the multipurpose cyclone/flood shelters before June, 2020. Tripathy also directed that the emergency equipment supplied to the shelters should be under the direct charge of the respective fire stations for keeping the machines in good working condition. He further directed to start training activities in State Disaster Management Center already set up in Gopabandhu Academy of Administration.

The center would be used as a temporary training center till completion of the State Institute of Disaster Management (SIDM), now under construction within the campus Revenue Officers Training Institute ( ROTI) at Gothapatana. The SIDM would be a state of art institution with world class training infrastructure, training modules and facilities. Target was set to complete construction of the building by March 31, 2021.

Chief Secretary Tripathy directed to have third party quality audit of the entire SIDM project.

Additional Chief Secretary Jena appraised that physical audits of the multipurpose cyclone/flood shelters have been completed in all 25 districts. At present, a total number of 879 shelters are in operation out of which 503 are Multipurpose Cyclone Shelters (MCS), 311 are Multipurpose Flood Shelters (MFS) and 65 are the MCS constructed by Indian Red Cross Society. It was decided to complete repair works before June, 2020. It was also decided to fix lightning arrester system in all the shelters.

Further, Jena said the OSDMA in collaboration with USA based firm Earth Networks has installed six lightning detection sensors in different parts of the State. The system gives prediction of the lightning about 30 to 45 minutes in advance, he added.

Map based lightning alerts are provided. It was decided that the Earth Networks will do validation of the lightning warnings provided to the OSDMA and would also monitor the lightning incidents on real time basis.

Title: Inbrief
Article:
Parents want schools closed

All school parents Association Jharkhand has urged the Jharkhand Government to close all government and private schools for few days as a precautionary measure against Coronavirus spread. State president of the association Ajay Rai said that the weather in Ranchi and other districts is changing fast with uneven temperature across the State. He said that the disease has taken the form of a pandemic and it is high time that the government should take the precautionary step. He said that schools and colleges in several states have been closed till March 31.

Encarta 2020 at DPS Ranchi

DPS Ranchi organised Encarta 2020 for the students of Classes III-IX in the session break after final exams. The programme was designed under two categories: Cognitive Enhancement and Persona Enhancement. The Cognitive Enhancement category included Olympiad classes, Public Speaking and Quiz sessions and the Persona Enhancement included learning of Self Management, Soft skills, Moral Values, and Sports. Principal Dr. Ram Singh said that the school believes that children should utilize their holidays in a way that is relaxing as well as learning. The time is for a jump start before the beginning of the new session and a perfect time to relax and rejuvenate.

Food stalls inspected at Lohardaga

Additional Chief Medical Officer Ranchi Dr Sanjeev Kumar inspected the various food stalls at Lohardaga station on March 13. During the inspection, the official checked the quality of the food items, production and expiry dates of the products, cleanliness around the stalls, medical history of the seller and documents of the stall were checked which were all found to be up to date. Lohardage station manager Robert Ekka was present during the inspection drive.

NAAD’20 at BIT Mesra

Dhwani- Music Club, Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra organised its annual inter-college music festival, NAAD’20 from 13th-15th March 2020. The festival witnessed presence of several famous music maestros, students and music lovers alike from different colleges.

The first night of the fest, Shadaj, kicked off in the CAT Hall from 5:00 The event saw melodious classical performance by the members of Dhwani, beautiful rendition of the song Tum Hi Ho by Manas and Group, performance by band Heatstroke. The band Kshatriya left the assemblage awestruck with a beautiful presentation of the song Raadhe. Music engulfed the entire CAT Hall after Plexus gave an enchanting performance of Muntazir. They were followed by the band Firdaus who captivated the audience with their performance.

Technical seminar at RRD

Ranchi Railway Division on Friday organised a technical seminar in the presence of DRM Neeraj Ambashtha. In the seminar, Junior Engineer, Senior Section Engineer and other employees of the Department of Electricity (TRD) working on the Board discussed in detail the difficulties faced in the work such as overhead equipment failure and their remedial work and mentioned them by power point presentation. Other departments like Engineering, Signal and Telecom, Operations and Electricity (General) were also discussed. After discussion, officials of various departments gave their suggestions while deliberating for solutions to the problems. ADRM (Infra) AS Yadav, ADRM (Op) MM Pandit, Sr DSTE S Oraon, Sr DE (Coordination) Amit Kanchan, Sr DOM cum CPRO Neeraj Kumar, Sr DEE (TRD) AR Das, Sr DEE (general) Kuldeep Kumar, DEE Deepankar Ghosh alongwith other officers were present on the occasion.

Book release at Bokaro Club

The book ‘Happimes' written by Biswajit Banerjee of humour and satire was unveiled on Bokaro Club premises here on Friday. This book satirises the social discrepancies inherent in the common events of ordinary life through short stories. Writer Biswajit, who is currently working as GM at Bokaro Steel Plant, said in his statement that it is very important to resort to humor and satire in order to avoid stress and depression in today's life. Executive Director of Bokaro Steel Plant Dr. AK Singh Director in-charge (Medical and Health Services) Mukul Prasad, Executive Director (Personnel and Administration) and Atanu Bhowmik, Executive Director (Operations) expressed their happiness in releasing the book and Encouraged.

ATVM starts at various stations

Keeping in view the passenger facilities on the Ranchi Railway Division, an ATVM (Automatic Ticket Vending Machine) has been set up at Ranchi, Hatia, Muri, Lohardaga and Jhalida stations for the passengers, so that the passengers should not queuing for tickets. It will save time of the passengers. Apart from this, the facility of Unreserved Ticket System (UTS App) is also available for the passengers. To make these facilities aware, a special awareness campaign was conducted by the Commerce Department of Ranchi Railway Division at Jhalida railway station on Friday in which passengers can use the facilities of ATVM and UTS App and they were informed about getting tickets.

Title: Maoist involved in Burkapal ambush attack surrenders
Article:
Three hardcore Maoists, including one who was involved in Burkapal ambush attack wherein 25 police jawans were killed in 2017, gave up arms, police said here on Friday.

They were identified as Kartami Vaga alias Badal alias Basant hailing from Kuknar region, Madkal Kamli of Aranpur and Madkam Beeju of Tongpal.

“Basant was deputy commander of Maoist platoon number 26 and had also worked as LGS (local guerrilla squad) commander in Katekalyan region. He carried a reward of Rs 8 lakh on his head,” a press release issued by the police said.

Likewise, Madkam Kamli was commander of Maoist training team and had also worked as militia commander. State government had declared a reward of Rs 5 lakh on his head, police said.

In the same way Madkam Beeju was member of section B of Maoist platoon number 24 and had a reward of Rs 2 lakh on his head, police informed.

Badal was part of Maoist team that had carried out deadly attack on police party in 2017 at Burkapal wherein 25 police jawans had died. He had also killed two surrendered Naxals in 2018 and 2019, police mentioned.

In 2016 he had killed two villagers one each at Sautanar and Kummakoleng village. Badal was also involved in incidents like IED blast and firing on police party.

According to police, Madkam Kamli had joined Maoist groups in 2010 and in 2012 actively participated in attack on police patrolling vehicle at Kirandul.

Madkma Beeju was also involved in different attacks on police party, police added.

Title: CMD flags off CCL Ke Lal Ladli chariot
Article:
Chairman-cum-Managing Director (CMD), Central Coalfield Limited (CCL) Gopal Singh on Friday flagged off CCL Ke LaaL Laadli awareness chariot (mobile van) from CCL headquarters in Ranchi that will move to command areas of the company to motivate students to participate in upcoming examination of the scholarship to be held in coming days.

On this occasion, Director (Technical /Opperations) VK Srivastava, Director Technical (P&P) Bhola Singh, Director (Personal) Vinay Ranjan, Director (Finance) NK Agarwal, GM (SD & Welfare) AK Singh and GMs/HODs were present to grace the occasion.

Speaking on the occasion Singh said that the chariot will visit different districts within the command area of CCL to create awareness about the pioneering Corporate Social Responsibility initiative of CCL. “Under this scheme the students belonging to the downtrodden section of society selected through a state vide test will get free coaching for IIT, lodging, schooling and boarding arrangements. The coaching will be provided by ex IIT alumni who are currently working in CCL,” he added.

The CMD said that since its inception in 2012 more than 75 students have cleared IIT mains examinations. “Many students are working with leading corporate sector companies. This year 11 students of the batch out of sixteen students, secured ninety percentile or higher in JEE Mains. Siddhant Shekhar topped the field with 99.25 percentile,” he added.

Lauding the effort of CCL, Singh said that CCL through its Kayakalp initiatives is trying to bring a transformational change in the society. He emphasized that there is no dearth of talented students in Jharkhand and with proper coaching and guidance the students will succeed in IIT exams and bring laurels to the State.

He reiterated that success rate of scheme is hundred per cent.

A large numbers of CCL employees were present on the flagged off ceremony. On the conclusion of the programme CSR GM AK Singh briefed about the ongoing CSR programmes running by CCL.

Title: NDRF team reaches Hazaribagh
Article:
A 20-member team of NDRF reached Hazaribag on Friday to find out reason of gas leak in the town on Thursday midnight. The gas leaked from an Ice factory situated at a residential area resulted in one death and more than 20 persons falling unconscious.

Malhar Toli, a residential area of Hazaribagh district headquarters, witnessed a sudden chaos after a gas leak from the ice cream factory late on Thursday night The sudden leakage of gas caused death of Kanchan Devi age 55 year and resident of Malhar Mohall, Hazaribagh, while more than 20 persons were admitted to hospital for treatment.

On Friday afternoon, a 20-member team of NDRF inspected the Ice Factory. Inspector Mohammad Kalam, who is leading the team, said that the gas in the tank has been emptied and now there is no danger. The valve of the gas tank was in a very dilapidated state, which led to gas leakage, he added.

Speaking about the reason of the gas leak Kalam said that Hazaribagh has been in blackout for the last four days. “The factory operator was keen to produce more ice in the same condition. As they are not skilled operators so they are not able to explain about the cooling system. The factory operators were forcing the machine for greater cooling which heated the machine and receiver. Due to this the receiver pipe and the valve got burst and the gas started to leak. If the operator was skilled, they sprayed water on the receiver getting hot but this could not happen and the pipe burst. Experts operating the ice factory said that the section pressure should be at 180 sections,” he added.

“Ammonia gas is prepared by mixing nitrogen and hydrogen gas.

It is not poisonous. But when entering inside the body, it causes difficulty in breathing due to which people can die. This gas causes eye irritation. Due to the leakage of gas in the night, the pigeons had an impact on their eyes and they fell on the ground and died,” said Kalam.

Sanjay Kumar, son of Jagdish Prasad, the operator of the factory, said that due to the power cut the valve got damaged which caused leakage of gas. We tried hard to close the wall but it broke, he added.

Meanwhile, the district administration has allocated six lakh rupees from the State Disaster Redemption Fund for the treatment of gas leak victims. DC Hazaribagh, BP Singh said that necessary action is being taken against the operator by sealing the factory.

Title: ‘Scindia’ like fear in C’garh Congress too: Brijmohan
Article:
Firebrand BJP legislator Brijmohan Agrawal in a statement on Friday said that so many leaders are facing neglect in Chhattisgarh Congress and several Scindias are likely to come to fore in near future here too.

Taking a dig on not calling Health Minister T.S. Singhdeo to the high level meeting on Coronavirus on Thursday evening, Agrawal said he was not alone but there are so many dissatisfied Congressmen facing the neglect as Jyotiraditya Scindia was feeling in Madhya Pradesh.

Strongly reacting to the comment of Agrawal, Pradesh Congress Committee’s state general secretary and chairman communication wing Shailesh Nitin Trivedi refuted the charges of any ‘internal bickering’ or any ‘neglect’.

Regarding allegation of neglect of Singhdeo, Trivedi said he was on Bhopal tour and there was no intimation that he had returned and that was why he was not called in the meeting.

Trivedi further charged that Agrawal himself was neglected for long and even being competent was denied the post of state BJP chief earlier. “We have not forgotten the resentment of Agrawal’s supporters who had then set ablaze the state BJP office,” he said.

He further advised the BJP leader for not giving any suggestion to Congress as to how to run the government in the state.

“There are so many dissidents in BJP and how could Agrawal forget how Lal Krishna Advani, Murli Manohar Joshi, Yashwant Sinha, Shatrughan Sinha, Arun Shauri, Sanjay Joshi were honoured in BJP”, he further added.

Title: ‘C’garh established new benchmark in MNREGA’
Article:
nChhattisgarh has established new benchmarks in MNREGA, opined state Panchayat Minister TS Singhdeo here on Friday.

He reviewed the progress of various departmental schemes like MNREGA, Pradhanmantri Avas Yojana, Mukhyamantri Samgra Vikas Yojana, Swachh Bharat Mission, National Rural Livelihood Mission and few others.

“Chhattisgarh by achieving various norms of MNREGA among top states of the country has established a benchmark and we need to keep up the good work,” Singhdeo said while patting the officers and department employees.

He directed officers to regularly visit villages for ensuring effective implementation of rural development schemes. He also told them to maximize pension, labour payment and scholarship payments through ‘Sakhi Bank’.

“This home delivery of banking services should reach to differently abled and elderly people living in far flung rural regions,” he said.

He stressed for ensuring sufficient availability of green and dry fodder at Gauthans and said for this development of pasture land should be included in key departmental works.

Title: Samrat died due to viral disease, say officials
Article:
Elephane ‘Samrat’ who had been attracting hordes of visitors at the Bhagwan Birsa Biological Park also known as Birsa Jaivik Udyaan for the last 21 years breathed his last on Thursday afternoon. According to the zoo officials, the elephant died because of acute viral infection which led to cardio respiratory failure.

“Prima facie, it appears that he had acute viral infection which caused widespread internal hemorrhage in all the vital organs including heart, lungs and liver. Professor Dr Gupta who conducted the post mortem is of the opinion that the death of the elephant is due to cardio respiratory failure as a result of suspected per acute viral infection causing widespread hemorrhagic changes in vital organs,” said Director of Birsa Zoological Park, D. Venkateshwarlu.

Samples collected from the post mortem have been sent to the laboratories for further tests to confirm the cause of the mammals’ death. The tests will be conducted at the labs located in Bhopal, Guwahati and at the Indian Veterinary Research Institute, Izzatnagar in Uttar Pradesh.

The incident occurred at around 1:30 pm on Thursday. The elephant had a hearty meal the previous evening but on the morning of March 12, he seemed quite restless. The zoo doctors administered an injection for colic at about 11 am.

“After the medication was injected, he must have had instant relief from the pain. ‘Samrat’ was also seen enjoying a bath a little while later which looked quite normal for him. Due to internal hemorrhage, nothing was visible on the outside and this is a very unfortunate incident for the Ranchi zoo,” said Dr. Ajay Kumar, a veterinary doctor at the zoo

As per the authorities this is a type of emerging disease which generally affects just elephants. This infection is very common in elephants and last year six elephants died at the Nandankanan Zoological Park, Bhubaneswar within a span of about 20 days.

‘Samrat’ was found abandoned in the jungles of Chaibasa by the then forest officials and was brought to Birsa Zoological Park in the 1998 when he was just three months old. According to the zoo authorities, he was rejected by his mother upon birth.

“When the elephant had first come to the Ranchi zoo, he was suffering from severe umbilical hernia for which he also underwent an operation at the Ranchi Veterinary College. He led an absolutely healthy life for 21 years, but unfortunately he caught the infection at his prime age,” added the zoo vet.

Presently, the Ranchi zoo has just one female elephant ‘Lucky’ left. The zoo has taken preventive measures to protect her as the elephants lived in the same enclosure. Sanitization of the entire enclosed space with anti viral spray along with some dietary changes to increase immunity has been administered.

Title: 13 firms retreat; 8 stall operation
Article:
A total of 13 of 86 large industrial houses that had signed MoUs with the State Government to establish industries during the last 20 years since the year 2000 have withdrawn their proposals.

Industries Minister Dibya Shankar Mishra informed this in the State Assembly in response to a question of BJD MLA Prafulla Samal on Friday. The firms which withdrew proposals include Posco and Arcellor Mittal.

The Minister also informed that 45 of the 86 firms had started production partially and fully and of them eight steel companies have stalled production.

Title: ‘Other women should come to a woman victim’s help’
Article:
Observation of the International Women's Week by the Working Women Cell, PPT concluded on Friday with a valedictory function held at the Officers’ Club.

Chief guest Odisha State Commission for Women Chairperson Dr Minati Behera said that if any woman is subjected to any kind of violence then other women should come in support of her without any prejudices. Awareness should be created among the women about their rights. The commission would serve as a watchdog for protection of their rights.

Commission Member Snehanjali Mohanty deliberated on various laws framed to ensure women’s right to equality and to live with dignity.

Guest of honour PPT Chairman Rinkesh Roy hoped that such deliberation would immensely help the womenfolk of the locality to understand their rights. PPT Deputy Chairman AK Bose said that despite 74 years of Independence, right to equality still remains a distant dream for women.

Paradip Ladies’ Club president Subhalaxmi Roy highlighted the challenges faced by working women in their day-to-day life. Compeering the programme, PPT CME Saroj Kumar Das told that in spite of progress of civilisation, gender inequality still exits in the society in the name of tradition due to women’s ignorance of their legal rights.

Coinciding with the observation of the International Women’s Day on March 8, various competitions like song, dance, debate and sports were held among members of the PPT Working Women Cell. The winners were awarded on Friday by the chief guest and other dignitaries. Working Women Cell Chairperson Susmita Sasmal gave the welcome speech and Convenor Bijaylaxmi Mohapatra offered a vote of thanks.

Title: Youth’s body found at Kanas railway track
Article:
A body of a youth with severe cuts and wounds was found lying on a rail track near Kanas Road station here on Friday.

The deceased was identified as Mohan Kumar Baral (19) of Jorakani village under the Delanga police station. Reportedly, Mohan was engaged in tent making works for a marriage function in Motori village and he was present there till 1.30 am on Thursday night.

After seizing the body, Khordha GRP with help of Sakhigopal police handed over the body to his family after conducting autopsy in hospital.

The body was first spotted on Friday morning by some local people, who informed the guard at the nearby Jagadalpur level-crossing and later, to authorities at the Motori station and police.

Locals said Mohan might have suddenly come under a running train, while he was jumping the rail lines in the night. However, the family of the deceased brought an allegation of murder.

Title: 8 Maoists killed in State in 2019: Report
Article:
Eight Maoists were killed and 50 arrested while 13 surrendered during 2019 across the State, said a report of the Assembly Standing Committee on Home Department tabled in the House.

It said that 44 Leftwing extremism incidents were reported in last year of which 12 were exchanges of fire between security personnel and Maoists.

The report of the committee, headed by BJD MLA Kishore Kumar Mohanty, also said police seized 21 guns, 30 Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) and large quantities of ammunitions during anti-Maoist operations.

Now, Maoist activities in the State are by and large under control, the report said. However, it added that the situation remains challenging in some parts of Malkangiri, Koraput, Kalahandi, Rayagada, Kandhamal, Nuapada, Balangir and Nabarangpur districts.

To review the situation in the LWE-affected areas and to carefully monitor the anti-Maoist operations carried out by State security personnel and the Central Armed Police Force, a State-level Unified Command under the chairmanship of the State Chief Secretary has been constituted the report pointed out.

Title: Traffic tower at Baleswar Stn Square soon
Article:
In a bid to augment the road traffic management of the town, the police here are taking initiatives including installing automatic signals at prominent squares, CCTV and positioning adequate manpower. These are done in a public private partnership mode.

On Wednesday, ground breaking ceremony of an integrated traffic tower was held at the station square.

The tower is being built with the financial assistance of the Rotary Club , Baleswar with a budget of about Rs 10 lakh.

The tower, in a pattern of Watch tower ( Ghanta Ghar), besides having traffic post, also will have automatic signaling system and clocks in four directions. Apart from this the arts and crafts of the district would find a place in the tower.

It may be noted although the Baleswar city had automatic traffic signaling systems in the major intersections including at FM Golai, Station square and Police line square with the financial support of the industrial houses in 2009, yet by a year or two, all of them turned defunct. Those couldn’t be made serviceable due to paucity of funds in the department when the industrial houses didn’t wish to spend further towards the repair or replacement of the gadgets.

Over last 10 years the traffic posts at major squares and circles have been manned manually by the police although in some major points the department installed CCTVs

“The traffic lights couldn’t be repaired or replaced due to financial bottlenecks . But CCTvs have been installed in 18 places in and around the city and about 12 others are in pipelines . These Cameras are not only helping in traffic management but also in the monitoring the movements of criminals and crime control,” said Traffic police station OIC Prasant Ransing.

The traffic control could be more effectively carried out once the encroachments are cleared and people become self conscious, he added.

“The administration, in some places ,is failing to evict the encroachments as the encroachers are influential people. Many a time, after eviction again the encroachments are put up in the same place by the same individuals or groups. More so , people lack parking senses which make difficult for providing a hassle-free traffic,” said another police official.

Title: House panel to probe temple fund deposit
Article:
The State Assembly on Friday formed a House Committee to conduct a probe into the deposit of Rs 545 crore belonging to the Jagannath Temple in the crisis-hit private Yes Bank.

The panel was formed on the Speaker’s direction after the House was adjourned twice over the demand made by BJP members.

As the House met, BJP members urged Speaker Surjya Narayan Patro to form a House Committee to probe the matter. As the Speaker told them to participate in the Question Hour discussion, they rushed to the Well of the House and shouted slogans. The Congress members were on their feet in support of the demand.

Later, the Speaker directed the Government Chief Whip to place a proposal for formation of a committee to look into the Jagannath Temple fund deposits. Accordingly, the panel was formed.

The panel headed by the Speaker would submit a memorandum to the Government of India and the RBI Governor relating to release of the funds from the Yes Bank.

MLAs Pradipta Naik, Bikram Keshari Arukha, Pramila Mallik, Narasingha Mishra, Debi Prasad Mishra, Laxman Munda, Tara Prasad Bahinipati, Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak, Subash Chandra Panigrahi, Mohan Majhi and Pratap Keshari Deb are members of the committee.

Title: Bomb hurled at Niali police outpost
Article:
In yet another incident of the deteriorating law and order situation in Niali of Cuttack district, a police outpost was bombed in the wee hours of Friday.

Reports said an unidentified miscreant hurled a crude bomb at the Kasarda police outpost under the Niali police station in the district and fled from the spot.

The incident took place around 3 am. Fortunately, no one was injured in the incident as the bomb hit a tree and exploded.

Later, the Niali police on suspicion detained one Purna Chandra Parida for questioning. The reason behind the hurling of the bomb was yet to be ascertained.

Title: ILS researchers selected for Nobel Laureate Meet
Article:
Dr Subhash Mehto, Post-Doctoral Fellow and Kautilya Kumar Jena, PhD Scholar working with the Institute of Life Sciences, Bhubaneswar have been selected to participate in the 70th Lindau Nobel Laureate Meeting to be held from June 28 to July 3 this year in Lindau, Germany.

Both have been selected through a global screening process by a review panel to join the meeting. Excellent young scientists from round the globe representing all-natural science disciplines will participate and have the unique opportunity to meet around 70 Nobel Laureates for cross-generational and interdisciplinary exchanges.

Dr Mehato and Jena are working in the area of Autophagy regulation and mechanism in cancer and infectious disease biology in the laboratory of ILS faculty Dr Santosh Chauhan.

Title: Vigil on foreign tourists in Koraput
Article:
The Koraput district administration has asked the local tourism and travel industry to provide all information on international visitors to the district in the wake of the coronavirus (COVID-19) threat.

The health department officials have asked hoteliers, travel agents, the authorities concerned at bus-stands and railway stations across the district to inform about the arrival of foreigners to the district.

Two isolation wards have been opened at the Saheed Laxman Nayak Medical College and Hospital and the District Headquarters Hospital. In the last one month, as many as 32 international tourists, mostly from Italy, have been screened at both the hospitals after their arrival. None were found positive for COVID-19.

Chief District Medical Officer Mokoranda Behera said health officials are alert and the situation is being examined every day.

Title: 5% Dearness relief for State pensioners
Article:
Following demands by employees over the pending Dearness Allowance (DA), the State Government has announced a 5%-Dearness Relief (DR) for its pensioners with retrospective effect from July 1, 2019.

With this, the Dearness Relief was enhanced to 17% from 12%.

The Dearness Relief (TI) on pension/family pension shall be paid to the State Government pensioners and family pensioners at the same rate of 5% on the revised basic pension/family pension with effect from July 1, 2019, according to a notification on Thursday.

Last month, the State Government had announced a 5%-DA hike for its employees and pensioners with effect from January 1, 2020 instead of July 1, 2019. However, the employees threatened to stage protest demanding release of five-month pending DA after hike by the Central Government for its employees.

With sanction of 5% DR for pensioners, the employees may now put pressure on the authorities to release pending amount from July 1, last year.

Title: Bargarh tribal folk dance enters Record Books
Article:
An attempt by a huge number of folk artists on the occasion of famous Karamsani festival in Bargarh district in January this year has borne fruit as the programme has found a place in the India Book of Records.

As many as 3,000 artists had played drums and moved to the beats of folk songs for half an hour at the programme titled ‘Dangar Upre Karamsani’ organised by the Sambalpuri Folk Academy at Mahajan Dunguri near Saradhapali village under Gaisilat block in Bargarh district on January 5.

All the artists showcased their skills by playing music and performing dance simultaneously at the festival coordinated by Guru Rabi Ratan Sahoo.

The artists’ skills were acknowledged following a verification by the Editorial Board of India Book of Records and the programme entered into the record book for ‘Maximum artists performing in Karamsani festival’.

Notably, Karamsani is a tribal festival celebrated within the fold of the Sambalpuri folk tradition. It is one of the cultural events in which the performers dance to honour the deity Karamsani.

Title: Baripada student forced to kneel down
Article:
A Class-IX student of the MKC High School here was allegedly mentally harassed by the school headmistress on Friday.

The student Sumit Kumar Sahu’s mother and member of school management committee Sasmita Behera, accused Headmistress Pragyan Paramita Jena of keeling down the boy intentionally during the prayer class. She lodged a complaint at the Baripada Town police station against Jena in this connection.

Sasmita said Jena passed sarcastic remark about the hairstyle of Sumit and punished him in front of others students and school teachers.

Demanding action against the headmistress, Sasmita further said though the State Government has declared schools as punishment-free zones, the act of headmistress caused mental strain to his son. “Sumit was unable to write his answer sheet during the English examination following the incident. Even he told me about taking the extreme step,” she further said.

The headmistress, defending her action, said that to discipline Sumit she asked him to kneel down. Four other students were also punished for violating the school discipline, she added.

Title: Bal elected RBA president unopposed
Article:
Senior lawyer Ramesh Bal was elected unopposed as the president of Rourkela Bar Association (RBA) after the scrutiny of nomination papers, said sources.

It may be noted here that the nomination for various posts of the RBA was held on March 5 and 6 and the verification was held on March 12. After verification, while Bal remained the sole candidate for the post of president, three contested for vice-president, two for general secretary and two were for treasurer. None contested for joint secretary post as all the nominations were rejected in scrutiny, revealed election officer Purna Chandra Pradhan. The final list of candidates will be notified on March 14 and voting is on March 28.

But the reliable sources said Sadananda Sahoo has withdrawn his candidature from the post of general secretary. So the other candidate Akhaya Sahoo will also be elected to the post uncontested.

It may be noted here that usually the RBA election is held in the month of December every year but this year as per the guidelines of State Bar Council (one bar one election in one day through out the State), this year it has been deferred to March.

Title: Divyang raped in Niali, accused detained
Article:
A divyang girl was raped in the Niali area of Cuttack district in the wee hours of Friday when she had gone to watch a Dola Melana festival.

According to reports, the accused took advantage of the crowd at the Dipoti Melana festival in the locality and dragged the victim to a secluded place near Padhai Sahi Chhak, where he raped her.

He also threatened the girl not to disclose the incident to anyone. Later, the victim informed her family about the incident, following which a complaint was lodged in this connection at the Niali police station.

Cops managed to track the accused and detained him for questioning. The accused was identified as a resident of Patrakana village in the area.

Title: Only 932 cooks, attendants to be regularized
Article:
As many as about 9,000 cooks and attendants are now working in various hostels and residential educational institutions run by the SC and ST Development Department. The services of only 932 of them are eligible to be regularised.

It was revealed from the information furnished by SC and ST Development, Minorities and Other Backward Classes Welfare Minister Jagannath Saraka in response to a question of BJD MLA Kishore Chandra Nayak on Friday.

The Minister said that the cook and helpers posted on or before April 12, 1993 are eligible to get regular jobs in sanctioned Class IV posts as per a notification issued by the Finance Department on September 4, 2012. Accordingly, 932 cooks and attendants have been appointed with temporary status recently. They would be regularised on sanctioned Class IV posts in their respective districts in a phased manner, the Minister said.

The Minister further informed that the cooks and attendants employed after April 12, 1993 are getting wages fixed for semi-skilled workers by the Labour and Employment Department and the Government has no plan to regularise them.

Title: Two youths drown in river in K’pada
Article:
Two youths drowned while taking bath in the Chitrotpala river near Patkura in Kendrapada district on Friday. They were identified as Sharif Khan of Kendrapada and Basan Khan from Mumbai.

According to sources, Sharif and Basan had come t their relative’s house to attend a function. In the morning, they had gone to the river to take bath and unfortunately drowned.

As they did not return back, the family members started searching for them and found slip-ons and a soap case at the spot.

Later, they informed the Fire Services about the incident. Fire Service personnel rushed to the spot and recovered the bodies from the river.

The bodies were sent to the Patkura Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC), where doctors declared them dead.

Title: 14,588 check dams built in 10 yrs: Min
Article:
A total of 14,588 check dams have been constructed in the State in last 10 years (2010-2019) irrigating 1,47,000 hectares of land. Water Resources (WR) Minister Raghunandan Das informed this replying to a question raised in the State Assembly on Thursday.

Further, the Minister said the Government has a target to construct 2,000 check dams in the 2019-20 financial year. A total of Rs 333.84 crore was earmarked for this, out of which Rs 302.23 crore has already been spent by February-end.

He said it was targeted to build 1,087 check dams in 2018-19. While works of 367 check dams have been completed, 720 are under construction.

Cornered by MLAs over the collapse of check dams in several places, the Minister said construction of check dams is not only carried out by the Water Resources Department but also by the Agriculture and SC/ST Development Departments and the dams constructed by the WR Department do not develop any defect.

Later, the Speaker directed the WR Minister to provide all members a list of the existing check dams. After receiving the report, the MLAs would assess the conditions of check dams in their respective jurisdictions and submit reports. On the basis of the reports, further necessary action would be taken in this regard, the Speaker ordered.

Title: Govt stops sporting events, asks people to avoid gathering
Article:
While the national Capital is under the grip of COVID-19, the Delhi Government on Friday ordered to stop all sports gathering in the city including Indian Premier League (IPL) 2020.

Citing social distancing the most effective way to contain the spreading nature of coronovirus, Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia said we are urging people to avoid large gathering as much as they can. Stressing on self- quarantine, Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) Ministers advised people to stop participating in mass gathering activities as six cases have been confirmed so far.

“Social distancing is the most effective way to stop the spread of the coronavirus cases in Delhi and India. To maintain social distancing, it is important to avoid any big event which witnesses huge public gatherings. “The IPL and such sports events witness huge gatherings, therefore, we have decided to stop such events with an immediate effect till the further order,” said Sisodia.

“I want to tell everyone to not wait for the Government orders but to proactively avoid any big gathering. The Government is doing their best but to stop the spread of Coronavirus, mutual cooperation of the people and the Government is very important,” the Minister added.

Adding furthermore, Sidodia said, “In Korea, the coronavirus was contained for the first 30 cases. Patient 31 was a super-spreader who passed it to thousands of other people. In order to prevent instances like this, the Delhi Government has ordered that no big gatherings should take place but if you find any such gatherings where people are coming from different places then please avoid such venues. We believe that such strict preventive steps are the only way to stop this disease and many other countries are following such steps.”

“This is exponential threat where every day counts. I would urge the people to self-quarantine themselves. If you have symptoms of COVID-19, get your tests done, avoid public gatherings and stay at home. This is best way to contain spread of this disease,”

Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain said.

Title: Cong targets Minister over his notice
Article:
The Congress has targeted Transport and Commerce Minister Padmanabha Behera again over a false affidavit row concerning his educational qualification.

In response to a notice sent by Minister Behera to Congress spokesperson Nishikanta Mishra for tarnishing his image over his allegation on February 16 that Behera gave false information on his educational qualification during filing his nominations at different times, which did not match, Mishra dared to face him in court with all documentary evidences.

Mishra in a Press conference on Friday asked why the police had not taken any action against Behera despite an Orissa High Court direction to take criminal proceedings against the Minister under People’s Representation Act, 1951 and IPC Section 171 A for submitting the false affidavit. Mishra also alleged one Bhagaban Bag, who moved the HC over the false affidavit issue of Behera, was being threatened and attacked by goons.

“It was expected that the Minister Behera would clear the air on his educational qualification with proofs for the people of the State. But instead of doing that he served a notice to save his face before his electorate,” charged Mishra. He also demanded that the Chief Minister who is claiming so much about transparency and 5T should take action against Cabinet Minister Behera for keeping the people of the State in dark over his educational qualification. Among others, Congress leaders Prasant Satpathy, Jinesh Das, Amita Biswal and petitioner Bag were present.

Title: Centre, AAP Govt working synergistically: CM
Article:
Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Friday said the novel coronavirus outbreak was at the containment stage, adding the Centre and the Delhi Government had been working together to deal with it.

Addressing a one-day session of the Delhi Assembly, the chief minister said his Government had been taking every step to check the spread of the pandemic.

“We have closed schools, cinema halls, universities... To contain the spread of coronavirus,” Kejriwal told the Assembly. “We have been taking all precautionary measures and people have been supporting us.”

“It is good that coronavirus is at the containment stage. The Centre the Delhi Government are working together to deal with it,” he said.

Kejriwal underscored that healthy people do not need to wear masks and precautionary measures, especially regular washing of hands, could help deal with the deadly disease.

“If you wear a mask, you may touch it and there’s is a fear of getting infected,” the Chief Minister said.

“Only infected people should wear mask.”

Health Minister Satyender Jain said more than 500 beds had been readied for COVID-19 cases. Private hospitals should be allowed to run testing laboratories, he added.

Title: Dist-level youth meet held at U’kote
Article:
The National Youth Organisation in collaboration with the Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan organised a district youth convention here on Monday.

The main objective was to sensitise the youth on current policies and schemes of the Union Ministry of Youth Affairs and also its special programmes in coordination with other ministries.

The main focus was on developing values of good citizenship, thinking and behaving in secular ways, skill development and helping youth to adopt a productive and organised behaviour.

Director, National Youth Organisation, Sameer Kumar Pradhan presided over the meet wherein local MLA Nitya Gond graced as chief guest. Some local youths were awarded for their achievements in different fields.

Among others, BDO Devi Prasad Teli, senior lawyer Srinibas Patnaik, engineer Chandana Malik and Tutu Babu Patnaik were present.

Title: Jamia, JNU suspends classes till March 31
Article:
Following the coronavirus outbreak, Jamia Millia Islamia (JMI) and Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) suspended classes on Friday with immediate effect till March 31.

JMI authorities also advised students to avoid large gathering.

JMI administration also decided to close all schools run by it till March 31, but said board examinations would continue according to schedule.

“Teachers should make study material available to students, who need any assistance, online. Teachers should contact the students via email for reference of study material available online,” stated the notification issued by the JMI administration.

“Face-to-face, group interaction or gathering of students were to be avoided till March 31. Internal assessment would be provided online. Seminars/conferences to be postponed with immediate effect and stay in the guest house to be restricted till March 31. University examinations will continue to be conducted as per schedule,” the notification further stated.

The university’s librarian said the library would provide customised services by way of downloading research and teaching material for onward circulation among students.

Earlier during the day JNU administration suspended its classes till March 31 but said that routine office work will remain unaffected.

According to Pramod Kumar, Registrar of JNU, in view of the situation arising out of coronavirus (COVID-19), it is hereby notified that all lectures, class presentations and examinations at JNU are suspended until March 31 with immediate effect.

“Conducting any event such as seminars/conferences/workshops in the campus during this period that require gathering of people should be postponed. Basic mess facilities will be available to the hostel residents during this period,” said Kumar.

Title: MV Act: Bus owner fined Rs 7L in Boudh
Article:
Officials of the Regional Transport Office, Boudh on Thursday imposed fine of a whopping Rs 7,07,230 on a bus owner for violating rules under the amended Motor Vehicle Act and being unable to present necessary documents.

During a vehicle checking near Ghantapada, the officials checked the bus, which was going towards Khuntigora from Bargarh, imposed the penalty on bus owner Sanjib Sahu and seized the vehicle.

A fine of Rs 5,000 was imposed for using the vehicle without registration and a fitness certificate, Rs 500 for general offence and Rs 5,000 for allowing the driver to drive the bus without a valid driving licence.

Besides, Rs 10,000 was imposed on the bus owner for violating air and noise pollution norms, Rs 10,000 for using the vehicle without a permit or violating permit conditions and Rs 2,000 for plying the bus without insurance.

The bus owner was also asked to pay Rs 6,74,730 as Odisha Motor Vehicle Tax from September 1, 2018 to March 31, 2020.

Title: JSPL celebrates Naveen Jindal’s b’day
Article:
Thousands of people, including employees and local villagers, celebrated the 50th birthday of Jindal Steel & Power Ltd (JSPL) Chairman Naveen Jindal and prayed for his welfare and long life.

JSPL-Odisha COO Pankaj Gautam and other senior officials attended cake-cutting ceremonies held at different locations.

Like every year, this year also Naveen Jindal’s birthday was celebrated as Fitness Day, A mega yoga camp was held under the guidance of yoga guru Swami Satyabindu Saraswati at Jindal Nagar Township.

Jindal Mahila Samiti and JSPL Foundation under the leadership of JMS president Pratibha Gautam and Puspalata Satapathy, GM-CSR, respectively, took up various charitable activities.

JSPL employees at Bhubaneswar office also celebrated Jindal's birthday. President & Group Head (CSR & Sustainability) Prashant Kumar Hota described Jindal as a true patriot who fought alone and won a long legal battle to give each and every Indian to wave the National Flag.

Title: Corona could be modern-day Bhasmasura
Article:
An epidemic is an event in which a disease is actively spreading. By contrast, the term pandemic relates to geographic spread and is used to describe a disease that affects a whole country or the entire world.

Throughout history, there have been a number of pandemics, such as cholera, plague, smallpox and tuberculosis. One of the most devastating pandemics was the Black Death, which killed an estimated 75–200 million people in the 14th century.

The 2019–20 corona virus pandemic is an ongoing global pandemic of corona virus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome corona virus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

The virus first emerged in Wuhan, Hubei, China in December 2019. On March 11, the World Health Organisation declared the outbreak a pandemic. As of March 11, over 1,26,000 cases have been confirmed in more than 110 countries and territories, with major outbreaks in mainland China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran. More than 4,600 have died from the disease and 67,000 have recovered.

In Hindu religion, Bhasmasura was an asura or demon who was granted the power by Lord Shiva to burn up and immediately turn into ashes (bhasma) anyone whose head he touched with his hand. Bhasmasura then tried to experiment it with Lord Shiva and then wreaked havoc across the world. It might be possible that COVID-19 is manmade virus developed in Wuhan research laboratory which has now turned into Bhasmasura. Lord Vishnu, in the form of Mohini finally killed him.

Viruses are very tiny germs. They are made of genetic material inside of a protein coating. Viruses cause familiar infectious diseases such as the common cold, flu and warts. They also cause severe illnesses such as HIV/AIDS, smallpox, and Ebola. The ancient virus is one of the most devastating diseases known to mankind. The extremely contagious disease small pox is caused by the variola virus. Humans have battled the virus for thousands of years. In the 20th century alone, smallpox killed 300 million people worldwide. WHO declared the virus had been eradicated in 1980.

Viruses are like hijackers. They invade living, normal cells and use those cells to multiply and produce other viruses like themselves. This can kill, damage, or change the cells and make you sick. Different viruses attack certain cells in our body such as our liver, respiratory system, or blood. When we get a virus, we may not always get sick from it. Our immune system may be able to fight it off. For most viral infections, treatments can only help with symptoms while we wait for our immune system to fight off the virus. Antibiotics do not work for viral infections. There are antiviral medicines to treat some viral infections. Vaccines can help prevent us from getting many viral diseases.

Viruses can be transmitted in a variety of ways. Some viruses can spread through touch, saliva, or even the air. Other viruses can be transmitted through sexual contact or by sharing contaminated needles. Insects including ticks and mosquitoes can act as "vectors," transmitting a virus from one host to another. Contaminated food and water are other potential sources of viral infection.

Thus it is advised to Wash your hands with soap and water thoroughly — and often. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer only if soap and water are not available. Also we should not touch our face, especially our eyes, nose and mouth. People should not be panic rather should maintain a neat and clean environment. Lord Vishnu will save us from the grip of COVID-19.

(Dr Senapati is Dean, Science, BPUT, Professor and Head, Dept of Chemistry, Trident Academy of Technology, Bhubaneswar)

Title: Ex-clerk gets RI after 16-yr trial
Article:
A retired Senior Clerk-cum-Accountant of a Government-run hospital in Ganjam district was on Friday convicted for misappropriation of funds after a 16-year-long trial. I Raja Rao, who worked in the City Hospital here, was convicted by the Court of Special Judge of Vigilance here. The court sentenced him to undergo two years’ rigorous imprisonment (RI) and pay a fine of Rs 10,000, and to undergo RI of three months more in default of payment of fine.

Notably, Rao was facing trial in a case registered in 2014 on the charge of misappropriation of Government money amounting to Rs 2,68,859 collected towards user charges and other funds in the hospital.

Title: STF arrests 4 brokers of city sex racket
Article:
The Special Task Force (STF) of Crime Branch on Friday arrested four persons for allegedly working as middlemen of a sex racket.

The accused were identified as Bidyapati Saha alias Ajaya of Mohiuddinnagar in, Bihar, Din Dayal Rao of Kajibazarm in Cuttack Alliuddin Khan of Barahala in Pipili and Sunil Maharana of Mahtab Road in Bhubaneswar.

During the course of investigation into a case, the STF conducted raids at different places of Bhubaneswar and arrested the four accused. The STF also seized two cars and nine mobile phones from their possession. Five women were rescued from the possession of the four persons while they were trying to hand over the victims to customers.

The four persons were associates of the main accused of a sex racket, Ruksar Begum, Preeti Padhi and Keshab Sahoo. In this case as of now a total of nine persons have been arrested and 14 victims were rescued from the clutch of the traffickers.

All the accused were later forwarded to court.

Title: Party workers miffed over Tirtol BJD polls
Article:
The recent BJD organisational elections in three blocks under the Tirtol Assembly constituency have raised eyebrows among the party’s rank and file not only in Tirtol but also throughout the politically conscious Jagatsinghpur district.

Hundreds of disgruntled party workers told this correspondent at Tirtol, Raghunathpur and Biridi that veteran political BJD leaders including Tirtol MLA Bishnu Charan Das were not even taken into confidence before filling of nomination, election and declaration of the result.

They alleged arbitrary and unlawful nomination and declaration of the name of three block presidents by district Retaining Officer Goutam Palit have caused unprecedented resentment and huge uproar among the genuine BJD workers of Tirtol Assembly segment.

Tirtol Block BJD president Basanta Mohapatra said, “The undemocratic modus operandi of the district Returning Officer Goutam Palit, party observer for Jagatsinghpur district Debasis Samantaray and State Returning Officer Pratap Keshari Deb has administered a terrible body blow to the BJD organisation of Tirtol.”

“If the party supremo and our popular Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik will not look into the mess of affairs of BJD organisation, it will have dangerous and detrimental repurcations for BJD in days ahead,” cautioned a BJD dedicated grass root leader of Raghunathpur block Saroj Kanta Swain.

When contacted, district Returning Officer Goutam Palit stated to have conducted the election in consultation with the district observer, SRO and MLA, Tirtol. But MLA Das bluntly denied any consultation with him.

Title: Poll reforms: What recent EC report lacks
Article:
After the Lok Sabha elections of 2019, nine working groups comprising of Election Commission of India (ECI) officials and State electoral officers were constituted, who have submitted a report on February 18.

The report contains recommendation for putting a cap on campaign expenditure by parties and candidates and bring in greater transparency in the domain. The ECI report has also suggested bringing in the social media and print media under the silent period ambit which is 48 hours before polling and online registration of voters at the age of 17.

But it seems the unsavoury practices prior to, and during elections and the their ramifications post elections are far from being controlled by such limited measures. It is an open secret that the first three general elections were held in a free and fair manner, but a degradation of electoral ethics and standards came into light in 1967, during the fourth general elections. And surprisingly, the electoral process which is the edifice of democracy has become the basis of political corruption.

The ground reality is that in every constituency, candidates spend crores of rupees for campaigning and propaganda and this exceeds far beyond the permissible limit of expenses, and this is coupled with incidents of violence, intimidation, booth capturing, etc during polling.

It is common that political parties field criminals for funds and muscle flexing to win elections and in return they are provided with political patronage and protection. The single most important criterion, that is assessed by the political parties irrespective of the ability and integrity of the candidates is, ‘winnability’ in the elections. As a result of which competent and educated candidates who can best serve the constituents fail to see a chance to participate and succeed in the process.

In a glance, under the regulations in vogue there is no limit on the amount a political party can spend in an election or on a candidate. But, the individual candidates’ spending for the Lok Sabha elections is Rs 50 – 70 lakh (depending on the State they are contesting), and Rs 20 – 28 lakh for Assembly election.

Interestingly, the EC had put in a regulation before 2019 elections saying that exit poll results could be broadcast only after the final phase of the elections were over. This was made to not let the prospective voters get misguided. In 2013, the EC expanded postal ballot voting in the country. Prior to that, only Indian staff in missions and defence personnel in a limited way could vote via postal ballots.

But the story is different now, since it has been extended to six categories of voters who can use the postal ballot: service voters, special voters, wives of service voters and special voters, voters subjected to preventive detention, voters on election duty and notified voters. Besides, political parties now need to report contribution in excess of Rs 20,000 to the EC for claiming Income Tax benefit. Further, declaration of criminal antecedents, assets, etc. by the candidates is now made mandatory and declaring of false information in the affidavit is an electoral offence punishable with imprisonment up to 6 months or fine or both.

Irrespective of what is being done so far and what is recently suggested by the EC, the challenges are manifold, like it is yet a distant dream to devise an apparatus to assure the voter that, there is transparency about the background of the candidates, to free the election processes from muscle and money power, to prohibit nexus between business and politics, availing all the citizens eligible to vote a comfortable, friendly and assured facilitation of vote casting, to assure a non-partisan role of media and efficient application of the model code of conduct.

Early this year, BJP general secretary Ram Madhav while speaking in a conference on “Indian Democracy at Work-Money Power in Politics” said, "I feel that the Election Commission has an important role. I feel that it should have its own cadre.” This indeed is an important suggestion to think about which can go a long way in ensuring an efficient way of functioning of the EC.

In a recent judgment, the Supreme Court said, “…this court was cognizant of the increasing criminalisation of politics in India and the lack of information about such criminalisation amongst the citizenry." Here the court laid the onus on political parties for publicising information on candidates who have criminal charges against them, along with the reasons for choosing them and also for rejecting others with clean records.

Besides, the direction comprised vesting responsibility on the EC to inform such non-compliance, if any, to the apex court. On this, former Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) SY Quraishi, said, “It is a step forward for electoral reforms but still halfway from cleaning up the system. They have basically culled out the 2018 order with stronger wording and time-bound compliance".

So, it appears despite all of this what the EC in its recent report has missed is, the essential suggestion to give more teeth to itself, which shall be beneficial in its fight against ‘vote buying’ and ‘hate speech’, which may include suspension of candidates to contest elections for five years or any other efficient and stringent measure.

(The writer is a lawyer and can be reached at sjyotiranjan3@gmail.com)

Title: 3 held for raping minor in Jeypore
Article:
Police on Friday arrested three persons, including a minor boy, on the charge of raping a minor girl in Jeypore Sadar police limits.

Though the incident occurred on March 10, the matter came to the fore after a police complaint was lodged on Friday.

Akash Nayak of Kumbhar Street and Mete alias Tushar Harijan of Kusumput are among the three accused.

Police recorded the victim’s statement under Section 164 CrPC and sent her for medical examination.

As per the complaint, the three persons riding a motorcycle obstructed the girl aged about 17 years at about 5 pmM on March 10. They dragged her to a nearby bush and sexually assaulted her one after another. They also threatened her with dire consequences if she disclosed the matter before anyone.

Title: Odia couple from Canada hospitalized
Article:
Amid the coronavirus scare across the world, a couple who returned from Canada to Titilagarh on March 11 was admitted to the Bhim Bhoi Medical College Hospital in Balangir on Friday.

As per reports, the couple works in Canada. After receiving information that their uncle passed away, the husband and wife reached Titlagarh to participate in death rituals.

When the husband and wife suffered from fever, they visited Titlagarh Sub-Divisional Hospital for medical examination.

The couple’s medical examinations were conducted in presence of Sub -Collector Sudhakar Nayak. Later, the administration not wanting to take any chances shifted the couple to the Bhim Bhoi Medical College Hospital.

The move was taken suspecting the couple might be infected with coronavirus, an official said on condition of anonymity.

Title: Assembly adjourned till Mar 29 for corona
Article:
In view of the fast-spreading Novel Coronavirus (Covid-19) and the number of such cases increasing in the country, the State Assembly was adjourned till March 29 as part of precautionary measures.

Speaker Surjya Narayan Patro adjourned the second phase of the current Budget Session till March 29 following a proposal presented by Government Chief Whip Pramila Mallick in the House on Friday.

However, Opposition BJP members opposed the proposal alleging that the Government is taking such a decision to avoid discussions over several serious matters.

“The proposal shows that the Government doesn’t want to hold discussions on important Demands of Grants of various departments and fears to face people in case it fails to withdraw Jagannath Temple fund of Rs 545 crore from Yes Bank after the maturity date of March 19,” alleged Leader of Opposition Pradipta Kumar Naik. Other members of his party also opposed the move.

However, the Congress supported the move. “The Congress stands by the proposal of adjourning the House till March 29 in view of people’s interest. Preventive measure is now a need of hour,” said Congress Legislature Party Leader Narasingha Mishra.

He said the AICC has also cancelled several public gatherins and rallies planned in Gujarat and other parts of the country in view of the Coronavirus situation.

Other Congress members like Santosh Singh Saluja and Tara Prasad Bahinipati, several BJD members and Parliamentary Affairs Minister also talked in favour of the proposal.

Following the debate, the motion was passed in a voice vote and the House was adjourned till March 29.

In protest, the BJP members staged a walkout.

Speaker said the Demands of Grants of various departments, which were scheduled to be discussion for 12 days, would be passed in guillotine on March 30 and Appropriation Bill on scheduled March 31.

Title: Book ‘Mere Sapne Ka Bharat' released
Article:
Book 'Mere Sapne Ka Bharat' by young writer Adya Bharti launched on Friday.

The book was released by Reference publication, Bhopal. It is written by Adya Bharti's published work 'Mere Sapna Ka Bharat' (Children's Poetry Collection) was released on Friday at the Children's Research Center, Bhopal.

Presiding over the event, senior litterateur and former director Nirala Srjanpeeth Devendra Deepak said that Adya's poems are poems that knock at the time of time. Her poems are not poems of lamentation. There are poems explaining the individual's obligation to the society. The topics that she chooses, which are not seen in the magazines of children's literature, is her originality.

Prakash Baratunia-Chancellor Central Ambedkar University, Lucknow said that Adya Bharti is a child litterateur who is currently living her childhood. Adya has recorded various achievements in art, literature and sports up to the national level.

Special guest Mahesh Saxena said that your creations have made a mark in Doordarshan, radio and newspapers. The contemplation seen in his poems at the age of 14 is undoubtedly inherited from him.

Saraswat guest Anita Saxena said in her statement that Adya's poem 'Absolutely water like Ho Tum' makes children experience the poetry of elders. The words of Urdu that came in it have also left a good impression.

Preeti Praveen Khare read poems in her beautiful style. She says that the very first poem in the collection is dedicated to Hindi.

Title: CM, Opp leaders join awareness drive
Article:
An awareness programme on Coronavirus (COVID-19) was held inside the Assembly on Friday, where Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik, Speaker Surjya Narayan Patro, the Deputy Speaker, Cabinet Ministers, Government Chief Whip, Congress Legislature Party Leader Narasingha Mishra and MLAs werepresent.

Patro stressed on wide awareness on Coronavirus to stay safe. Health Minister Naba Das told how his department was ready to face the crisis. The Chief Secretary and Health Secretary among others also spoke.

Later, the CM and other dignitaries washed hands with soaps to send a message on maintaining personal hygiene.

Title: Edu institutions, cinemas closed till March 31
Article:
As a precaution against corona infection, the State Government on Friday announced closure of all educational institutions, excepting for purpose of examinations, and asked authorities not to hold non-essential official gatherings such as seminars, workshops and conferences till March 31. Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik made a statement in the State Assembly in this regard.

He said social gatherings and assemblies like religious functions, marriage receptions, parties are to be regulated by local authorities. Cinema halls, swimming pools and gyms would remain closed till March 31.

“Being at home, reducing social interactions and avoiding gatherings will cut down the vulnerability of Coronavirus contact to a great extent,” he said.

The Chief Minister advised all to wash hands frequently and maintain sanitation. “With the support of Members, the State will promote this on a mission mode,” he said.

“I appeal to every section of the society to behave in the most responsible manner. Rumour mongering, misinformation and irresponsible conduct will be dealt with very sternly,” he said.

The Chief Minister’s grievance cell and the joint grievance cells at the district level would also remain closed till March 31.

Title: Public meetings in Twin City cancelled
Article:
With directive by the State Government in view of rapid spread of coronavirus, the Twin City Police Commissionerate expedited initiative to cancel its orders allowing holding public meetings in Twin City with immediate effect.

“The orders that were given by Commissionerate Police earlier for holding public meetings in Twin City are cancelled from today till further order,” said Police Commissioner Sudhansu Sarangi today.

“If the Health Department seeks any help from Commissionerate Police, we will provide all sorts of assistance to people suspected with coronavirus to reach the hospital for tests,” he said.

Action will be taken against people for not following the Government regulations.

Expressing concern for police personnel staying in barracks, Commissionerate Police directed to grant leave to concerned cops complaining of illness.

“As per medical reports, leave will be granted immediately if any police personnel complains of sickness,” Sarangi said.

Also, attempt is being made to put police personnel with suspected coronavirus symptoms in isolation, he added.

Title: in briefs
Article:
Guv expels 6 Cabinet members on CM’s advice

Bhopal: Governor Lalji Tandon has expelled 6 members of the Cabinet with immediate effect on the advice of Chief Minister Kamal Nath. The names of these Ministers are Imarti Devi, Tulsiram Silavat, Govind Singh Rajput, Mahendra Singh Sisodia, Pradyuman Singh Tomar and Prabhuram Chaudhary.

Committee for promotion of logistics sector

Bhopal: The State Government has constituted a committee under the chairmanship of the Chief Secretary for promotion of logistics sector and natural gas pipeline projects in the State.

Under the work allocation rules of the State Government, the committee will give suggestions as regard to the inclusion of matter of logistics and natural gas pipeline under the authority of Industrial Policy and Investment Promotion Department.

The committee will also give suggestions in connection to the analysis and simplification of regulatory requirements/ permissions/ opinions with respect to the logistics sector and natural gas pipeline projects. The committee will submit its report to the state government within a month.

The Additional Chief Secretary General Administration, Additional Chief Secretary Finance, Additional Chief Secretary Energy, Principal Secretary Industrial Policy and Investment Promotion, Principal Secretary Food & Civil Supplies and Consumer Protection, Managing Director Madhya Pradesh Warehousing and Director level officers of Logistics Corporation, Food Corporation of India, Central Warehousing Corporation, Container Corporation of India, Gas Authority of India Limited have been inducted as members of the committee. The Managing Director of, M.P. I.D.C. has been made member secretary of the committee.

55,527 cases of faulty power dues resolved

Bhopal: Energy Minister Priyavrat Singh has informed that more than 55,527 cases have been resolved by the committees constituted for power distribution to solve faulty power dues from June 2019 to January 2020. A total of 1,210 committees have been formed in the entire State. As many as 13,249 cases have been resolved by the three power distribution companies in June-July, 11,349 in August, 8039 in September, 6,945 in October, 5105 in November, 6,016 in December and 4,824 cases in January. Singh has instructed to provide the right electricity bill to the consumers at the right time.

holiday in schools in view of Corona

Bhopal: The State Government has temporarily declared a holiday in all government and private schools of the state till further orders to protect against the Novel Corona virus (Covid-19) and disease caused by it. Principal Secretary School Education Department, Smt. Rashmi Arun Shami has issued instructions in this regard to all schools. Instruction has been issued that examinations of Class V and VIII will be conducted as per pre-fixed schedule. The annual examinations of Class 10th and 12th (whether they are being conducted under the aegis of any competent board / management) will be conducted as per the pre-fixed schedule.

During the holiday period, all the teaching and non-teaching staff in all the government schools will be present in the school and will do official and academic work. Private schools will be able to take a decision in their own discretion regarding the presence of teaching and non-teaching staff in the school.

Online admissions in Govt and pvt colleges

Bhopal: Admissions will be online in all Government and private colleges in the State for the academic session 2020-21. Higher Education department will conduct e-admission process in three phases from May 11 at graduation level and from May 21, 2020 at post-graduate level. In the first phase, the admission process will take place and in the other two phases, Centralized College Level Counseling (CLC) will be proposed. At the time of registration, applicants will be able to fill their choice by selecting 15 colleges / courses instead of maximum nine.

The Principals of all the universities and the colleges have been instructed by the Department of Higher Education to conduct examinations on time and declare the results. Under the e-admission process, it will be mandatory for all colleges to upload courses / subjects, no-objection certificates and affiliation of universities on the portal from April 1 to April 30.

62,350 tribal students get housing allowance

Bhopal: The State Government has provided an amount of about Rs 72 crore as housing allowance to 62,350 students of tribal class to help in college studies. This assistance has been made available to students for whom hostel facilities have not been made available. Last year, financial aid for housing was provided to about 28,500 students.

Special attention is being paid to the training of teachers to improve the quality of education in government schools run by the Tribal Welfare Department. Principals have been imparted training through Indian Institute of Management (I.I.M.) Indore. Through the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Gandhi Nagar, 25 Science and 25 Mathematics teachers have been trained as source teachers.

As many as 25 P.G.Ts and 29 T.G.Ts of the Tribal Welfare Department have been trained according to the new educational technology through C.B.S.E. New Delhi. In addition, honorarium of CTET pass guest teachers in Eklavya Model Residential Schools has also been increased.

Screening camps held during world Glaucoma week

Bhopal: During world Glaucoma week, 3 free screening camps were organised at Shujalpur, Akodiya and Sewa Sadan Eye Hospital, Sant Hirdaram Nagar. Out of 82 patients screened in Sewa Sadan 24 Glaucoma patients were identified.

Similarly, at Shujalpur, screening of 165 patients was done. Of them 7 were Glaucoma patients.

At Akodiya 4 Glaucoma patients were identified out of 78 screened patients. These camps were organised with the help of International NGO, CBM.

World Glaucoma week concludes on Friday. As many as 89 and 41 free spaces were also dispensed to the patients of poor vision of Shujalpur and Akodiya respectively.

Glaucoma specialists Dr Samta Patel, Dr Sapna Srivastava and Dr Deepa Raidas Singh have examined the patients in Sewa Sadan Eye Hospital.

Ceramic Pottery workshop from March 16

Bhopal: Under the series of skill development programme conducted by Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahalaya Bhopal, a two months long Ceramic Pottery workshop will be organised from March 16 to May 15, 2020 at IGRMS campus.

In this workshop training regarding different phases of Ceramic pottery making will be given by artist Dulal Chandra Manna. In the first phase of this workshop, the most common techniques of making pottery of various shapes and other materials by hand with specially prepared terracotta clay, such as pinch, koel, slab technique and chalk will teach and the use of simple wooden tools and participants will be made aware of the methods of trimming and finishing of pottery.

The final phase will be confined to the glaze making of pottery and firing in the kiln at 10,500 – 11,000 Fahrenheit temperature. After completion of the workshop certificates will be awarded to the participants.

Internal annual exams in all schools postponed

Bhopal: The State Government has postponed internal annual examinations in all schools of the state to prevent spread of Corona Virus. Commissioner Public Education and Director State Education Centre, Jayashree Kiyawat has instructed all the districts in this regard.

All the schools have been directed to postpone all the internal annual examinations, including Classes I to IV, and Classes VI and VII, to be conducted internally. This instruction will be applicable in all Government and non-government schools of the State.

It is worth mentioning that as per the order issued by the School Education Department, the annual examinations of Class Vth and VIIIth board in Government schools and the board examinations of Class Xth and XIIth will be conducted according to the pre-determined timetable. In addition to board examinations in private schools, all internal examinations will be postponed till further orders.

Title: Govt, pvt hosps to have Covid-19 cells
Article:
The Health and Family Welfare Department on Friday issued various regulations in view of the novel coronavirus outbreak under the ‘COVID-19 Odisha Regulations, 2020’ approved by the State Cabinet earlier on the day.

The regulations will remain valid for a period of one year.

Now, all Government and private hospitals should have COVID-19 corners for screening of suspected cases. The hospitals during screening will record the travel history of person to any country or area where COVID-19 has been reported. In addition, the history of contacts of the suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19 would also be recorded.

In case the person has any such history of travel to affected areas in the last 14 days and he/she is asymptomatic, the person must remain in home quarantine for 14 days from the day of exposure. Persons who do not observe the Home Quarantine Guidelines shall be quarantined in the quarantine facilities set up by Government.

The regulation has also prohibited COVID-19 tests. The private healthcare institutions intending to test COVID-19 must send their test samples through the State IDSP unit. The State IDSP unit will arrange testing strictly as per the guidelines issued by Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), New Delhi.

Title: Haryana closes school, colleges in 5 districts
Article:
A day after the Haryana Government declared coronavirus an epidemic. The State Government on Friday ordered schools, colleges and other educational institutes to remain closed to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

The Haryana Government on Friday decided to close all colleges and universities in five districts located adjoining the national Capital till March 31 as a precautionary measure in the wake of the deadly coronavirus.

This was stated in a press statement by the State’s Higher Education Department. All Government and private schools in Gurugram, Rohtak, Sonepat, Jhajjar and Faridabad districts, in the neighbourhood of Delhi, will be closed till March 31. However, students in these districts will take their exams as per schedule, according to a school education order.

However, the schools in other districts of the state will function as usual.
